From: LambApe <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: marsyas-users@lists.sourceforge.net
Subject: Marsyas Audio Tag Classification problem
Hello all,

I've been using Marsyas to reproduce some audio tagging task, and the results were unsuccessful. Help is needed.

- System: MacOS 10.6.8
- Marsyas version: marsyas-0.4.4 from SourceForge.
- Compiling: compiled with MAD, LAME and SWIG, using ccmake.
- Training/testing data: the as-is CAL500 data set.
- Instructions: "MIREX 2010 Audio Tag Classification" from MIREX/README_2010.txt
- Reference: the "Improving automatic music tag annotation using stacked generalization of probabilistic SVM outputs" paper.

Initially I chose 10-fold cross-validation on CAL500. The training list files were in the MIREX 2010 form (http://www.music-ir.org/mirex/wiki/2010:Audio_Tag_Classification#Training_list_file) for totally 174 tags represented by "1" to "174".

Then "> bextract -ws 1024 -as 400 -sv -fe -bf ..." was used for feature extraction. A warning message

"collectionName = MARSYAS_EMPTY
[MRS_WARNING] MarSystem::getChildMarsystem(): Flux/flux not found!
[MRS_WARNING] MarSystem::linkControl - Error creating new link control: Accumulator/acc/Series/featureNetwork/Flux/flux/mrs_bool/resetis an invalid path
Downsampling factor = 1"

appeared every time, but I just ignored it, until I got 10 .arff files for my training lists and 10 .arff files for my testing lists. Then I used "kea" as in the readme file, except changing the unfound "-tc" with "-tw", to perform the first stage automatic tag annotation.

The problem was: I ran through the whole process three times, and in 10 folds there was always one fold in which the model was ill-trained, generating affinities files that have probabilities all on the order of e-14, and blank predictions files.

Then I switched to 2-fold cross-validation to see if the same problem happened again, and it did. For each trial, either one fold or both two folds would produce the problematic affinities files.

Then I suspected it was due to some short songs and the sparse tagging matrix of CAL500, so I removed 4 songs which last less than 10 seconds, keeping only the five most frequent tags for my training files, and re-ran the 2-fold cross-validation several times. However the same problem persisted, either one or both two folds failed.

Please help me if anyone who has experience with CAL500 and Marsyas knows what caused the problem. (was it because of the CAL500 data, or the way I performed the task, or else?)

Many thanks,

LA





From: None
To: None
Subject: None


-- 
LambApe
Sent with Sparrow (http://www.sparrowmailapp.com/?sig)

recommend New York, for the art scene here is about 30 years lagging behing
Europe or Japan, seriously.

the teaching quality in each particular school, concerning art and design,

everyone...

> > 1, I know how to tell original German ECM prints from American prints,
> but
> > is there also any difference between the German prints?
>
> German paper sleeves are precision-printed (compare the sleeve spines,
> and you tell in 1 second), with thin paper, and often with different
> surface designs that are omitted altogether in US printing. E.g., the
> Luminescence LP by Jarrett, Garbarek originally had embossing, and
> fine, white, hairy paper, but was a complete flat mess on glossy paper
> in US ed.  Also many GErman ECM sleeves have a very thin gloss film
> over the paper -- never on US sleeves.
>
> German LPs use "virgin vinyl" as material, and the discs are very very
> thin, with completely flat, equal thickness all around. US LPs are
> thick on the circumferences. Holes are often off-centered. and the
> label printing have smearing ink on bad paper.
>
> If you've seen classical LPs by Deutsche Grammophone, then German ECM
> has the same quality and look, printing, etc. They use the same
> manufacturers.
>
> US. press ECM LPs have LOTS of noise, even played first time, but
> German ECM are noiseless, esp. when played for the first time.
>
> > 2, for the Paradigm Reference V20, the speakers each have four connecto=
rs
> on
> > the back(two blue, two red), should I connect them all to the amp?
> Because
> > now I only use one pair for each of the speakers, connected to the Syst=
em
> A
> > slots of the amp, and they work, so...
> >
>
> You are using it correctly (provided that the connectors connecting
> the two pairs for each channel are screwed in place). When the golden
> connectors are taken off, the BASS and TREBLE speakers can be powered
> separately by TWO DIFFERENT amps.... that's called "bi-amping"
>
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bi-amping
>



--=20
Gol Ng=FBang, 2010


From: <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>

e
semi-rare recordings like Hogiuta by T. Hino or the Rainbow Goblins bhe price can easily go to 30 =
bucks, unacceptable!! I got one Michal
Urbaniak's Live Recording(Polish Jazz series) for 15, the sleeve of which i=
s
quite used but disc in fair condition... Are these normal prices for such
recordings?

>> and you tell in 1 second), with thin paper, and often with different
>> surface designs that are omitted altogether in US printing. E.g., the
>> Luminescence LP by Jarrett, Garbarek originally had embossing, and
>> fine, white, hairy paper, but was a complete flat mess on glossy paper
>> in US ed.  Also many GErman ECM sleeves have a very thin gloss film
>> over the paper -- never on US sleeves.
>>
>> German LPs use "virgin vinyl" as material, and the discs are very very
>> thin, with completely flat, equal thickness all around. US LPs are
>> thick on the circumferences. Holes are often off-centered. and the
>> label printing have smearing ink on bad paper.
>>
>> If you've seen classical LPs by Deutsche Grammophone, then German ECM
>> has the same quality and look, printing, etc. They use the same
>> manufacturers.
>>
>> US. press ECM LPs have LOTS of noise, even played first time, but
>> German ECM are noiseless, esp. when played for the first time.

>> System A

>> >

>> the two pairs for each channel are screwed in place). When the golden

>> separately by TWO DIFFERENT amps.... that's called "bi-amping"

From: LambApe <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Yeniu Pan <yeniupan@gmail.com>
Subject: Re:
ok 

for an easy downloading of all the links shown in the webpage:
http://avaxhome.ws/video/genre/Melodrama_Romance/One_Day_2011_1080.html

you'll see "Download: Filesonic, Wupload..." in the bottom. filesonic is ok. click that little "+" icon and the links will unfold.

now, you'll like to download a "downloading tool" first, it's called JDownloader:
http://jdownloader.org/download/index

after you've downloaded and installed the JDownloader, open it;

select the 19 links on the webpage (from part01 to part19.rar) and copy them all;

click the "Linkgrabber" button in the JDownloader, you should see that the 19 links are displayed in the window. click the start button (the triangle) on the upper left, and you are all set. the software will automatically queue and download all the files for you (except that you might have to key in the Captcha for every file, so be aware once the icon of the software prompts you.)

if any doubt, just ask me anytime.

From: <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Eran Fishler <eran.fishler@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: YG2259 Final
Dear Professor,

This is Yuan Gao, currently a second-year graduate student in Electrical
Engineering, Columbia University. It has been a while since I took your
Linear Systems class last year. I hope everything is going well with you.

I take the venture to write to you because I'm at the moment of applying
for Ph.D. programs in several schools, and a few recommendation letters are
needed. If it's possible, I'm hoping that you can write one of them for me.

I'm asking for your help because, the programs I apply to are either in
EE/CS or Music Technology, in which statistical models, machine learning
and signal processing are heavily involved. Among all the classes I've
taken in Columbia, yours is one of the few that is related to these topics.
I understand that this could be inconvenient for you, and I'd appreciate
your consideration. Hope to hear from you soon.

Best regards,

Yuan Gao
mobile: 646-688-8554

On Apr 1, 2012, at 20:55, Dajuin Yao <dajuin@gmail.com> wrote:

> oh, BTW, i would suggest you getting a TENOR SAX, rather than alto,
> not only because of body size, but also tenor is more complex and
> expressive sound-wise, and can play lots of "harmonics", whereas alto
> is really stiff and limited in tone.



From: LambApe <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Dajuin Yao <dajuin@gmail.com>
Subject: Re:
That is really COOL. Kudos to your performance (anywhere I can hear it=3F=
) and that guy having the ears to recognize and appreciate it. I'm a litt=
le curious about the =22website=22 of yours the guy mentioned, which one =
is it=3F

Speaking of the stale and deadly rigid =22european academia=22, I can't h=
elp but notice that there really lies a huge problem in the way people li=
sten to and judge music (especially today's =22new=22 music), that is sti=
ll largely under the sway of those higher powers (The Wire or Simon Reyno=
lds alike) and those illusion-inducing retailers/promoters (Bleep, Boomka=
t and even Matemkine alike). The public judgement and taste on music are =
so dead. So dead.

I listened to Oneohtrix Point Never this afternoon, a new =22experimental=
=22 musician and a hotshot in the =22new music scene=22 (The Wire even ha=
iled one of his albums as the second best album in some year). It makes m=
e sick, real sick. Nowadays people just brag and boast about all these ki=
nds of soulless shit and pay no fucking attention to something really wor=
thing the praise. Like =46errous. I have to use =46errous's music to wash=
 my ears after finishing the OPN album. This world is so sick.

From: LambApe <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Dajuin Yao <dajuin@gmail.com>
Subject: quick question
DJ:

A friend wants to buy a turntable for makeshift use. I found this:

http://www.amazon.com/Technica-AT-LP60-Automatic-Driven-Turntable/dp/B002GYTPAE/ref=sr_1_1?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1337629239&sr=1-1

The specifications say it has a built-in "phono" pre-amp. Does that mean it can be connected to a pair of small speakers directly? (Like the Sony SS-B1000 speakers shown in the same page.)

From: LambApe <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Dajuin Yao <dajuin@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: quick question
Yes, you're right...

This is another solution I can think of (again, for makeshift use):

http://www.amazon.com/Crosley-Revolution-Portable-Turntable-Color/dp/B004FJYUW6/ref=sr_1_54?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1337630755&sr=1-54

This one has a headphone jack, so I'm thinking about connecting it to my friend's iMac audio input, using the software LineIn to directly route the sound to iMac's built-in speakers?


On Monday, May 21, 2012 at 3:52 PM, Dajuin Yao wrote:

> Lamb,
> 
> NO. Phono preamp merely means that you can plus the RCA outputs from
> the turntable directly into the RCA inputs of an ordinary amp of today
> (which does not support the old turntables as input source). You
> still need a regular "amplifier" to drive the speakers.
> 
> DJ
> 
> 
>

To: yu chen <StanlyChen208@gmail.com>
Subject: request
Stanly:

The book is called "Antonin Artaud Collected Works", if you look it up in
the library system you'll know where it is.

This series of books has 4 volumes, and in it there's a script/screenplay
called "The Seashell and the Clergyman". That's the one I need.

Thanks!!!!!

>   =20
> =20
> (New York, NMarch 19, 2012On April 13, the Gugg=
enheim will introduce Divine Ricochet (http://web07.echosentinel.com/web0=
7/l.do=3Fcid=3D60&mid=3D25185&e=3Dlvcrat.wvnat=7Etznvy.pbz&t=3D326545&=7E=
cid%3D60%26mid%3D25185%26fn%3DLIB120316120103cTav1%2Ehtml%26tn%3D%26ft%3D=
stored%26rid%3D1%26mt%3D%26e%3Dlvcrat%2Ewvnat%7Etznvy%2Epbz), a three-par=
t series of live music accompanying the John Chamberlain: Choices (http:/=
/web07.echosentinel.com/web07/l.do=3Fcid=3D60&mid=3D25185&e=3Dlvcrat.wvna=
t=7Etznvy.pbz&t=3D326546&=7Ecid%3D60%26mid%3D25185%26fn%3DLIB120316120103=
cTav1%2Ehtml%26tn%3D%26ft%3Dstored%26rid%3D1%26mt%3D%26e%3Dlvcrat%2Ewvnat=
%7Etznvy%2Epbz) retrospective, on view at the museum through May 13, 2012=
.  Produced by Sam Brumbaugh, Special Events Consultant, and Bronwyn Keen=
an, Director of Special Events, the series takes its thematic cue from th=
e poetic fusion, chaotic riffing, explosive color and sublime assemblage =
that characterized Chamberlaiwork. The series title Divine Ri=
cochet is borrowed from a 1991 work by Chamberlain and features the artis=
signature use of wordplay.  A great lover of music, Chamberla=
in pushed boundaries as he explored abstraction, rhythm, harmony, and dis=
sonance, providing a vibrant context for contemporary musical experiments=
 in the Guggenheim rotunda.
> =20
> Divine Ricochet (http://web07.echosentinel.com/web07/l.do=3Fcid=3D60&mi=
d=3D25185&e=3Dlvcrat.wvnat=7Etznvy.pbz&t=3D326547&=7Ecid%3D60%26mid%3D251=
85%26fn%3DLIB120316120103cTav1%2Ehtml%26tn%3D%26ft%3Dstored%26rid%3D1%26m=
t%3D%26e%3Dlvcrat%2Ewvnat%7Etznvy%2Epbz) commences with loops and layerin=
g of voice by Juliana Barwick and Groupesite-specific perform=
ance Violet Replacement, comprising long-form ambient pieces on =46riday,=
 April 13; followed by the melodic synthscapes and experimental electro-p=
op of Cold Cave on =46riday, April 27; and then by a one-of-a-kind perfor=
mance of thumping ballads and electronic glitch by the commanding Zola Je=
sus on Thursday, May 10.
> =20
> Doors open at 8:30 pm and guests are invited to view the current exhibi=
tion John Chamberlain: Choices (http://web07.echosentinel.com/web07/l.do=3F=
cid=3D60&mid=3D25185&e=3Dlvcrat.wvnat=7Etznvy.pbz&t=3D326548&=7Ecid%3D60%=
26mid%3D25185%26fn%3DLIB120316120103cTav1%2Ehtml%26tn%3D%26ft%3Dstored%26=
rid%3D1%26mt%3D%26e%3Dlvcrat%2Ewvnat%7Etznvy%2Epbz) before the performanc=
es, which start at 10 pm in the museufamed =46rank Lloyd Wrig=
hesigned rotunda.
> =20
> Tickets
> Priced at =2427 for nonmembers and =2422 for members, tickets are limit=
ed and available through advanced online ticket sales only at guggenheim.=
org/ricochet (http://web07.echosentinel.com/web07/l.do=3Fcid=3D60&mid=3D2=
5185&e=3Dlvcrat.wvnat=7Etznvy.pbz&t=3D326549&=7Ecid%3D60%26mid%3D25185%26=
fn%3DLIB120316120103cTav1%2Ehtml%26tn%3D%26ft%3Dstored%26rid%3D1%26mt%3D%=
26e%3Dlvcrat%2Ewvnat%7Etznvy%2Epbz). Grouper and Julianna Barwick tickets=
 will go sale March 20 for members and March 21 for nonmembers. =20
> =20
> =46riday, April 13: Grouper and Julianna Barwick
> Grouper is the solo project of Portland based musician/artist Liz Harri=
s. Since the release of her recently acclaimed album A/A : Alien Observer=
 (2011), Grouper has scored the Sundance favorite The Perception of Movin=
g Targets, and has been working on projects with both Tiny Vipers and Nin=
ja Tune producer The Bug (Kevin Martin). Grouper's stately chorded songs =
have been described by Wire magazine aounding as if they'd be=
en made against a vast mountainside: voice and instruments-muted piano, s=
pider strummed guitar and growling drone steeped in reverb and delay=9D Grouper's site-specific Violet Replacement performance in the Guggenh=
eim rotunda will be naturally resonant and comprise long-form ambient pie=
ces that include tape loops, field recordings, Wurlitzer loops, and subme=
rged atmospherics mixed and processed live from an array of dictaphones a=
nd tape players.
> =20
> Brooklyn-based solo artist Julianna Barwick creates music which is at o=
nce orchestral, choral, and meditative, using her voice as an instrument =
to create soaring, capacious chants and mystical invocations. Barwick has=
 been compared to the likes of Philip Glass, Brian Eno, Panda Bear, Stars=
 Of The Lid, and Cocteau Twins. The musician builds multiple loops and la=
yers off a single refrain, and State magazine described her live performa=
nce as composed oordless songs with transporting power=9D where Barwictood alone but sang like a choir of angels.=E2Barwick will open for Grouper on April 13.
> =20
> =46riday, April 27: Cold Cave
> Heirs to the synthpop noir of New Order, Throbbing Gristle, Soft Cell, =
and Muslimgauze, Cold Cave are an experimental electronic pop group from =
Philadelphia and New York who make melodic synthscapes with driving beats=
. Celebrating the contradictory beauty of the human condition, Cold Cave =
acknowledges the dark roots of synthesizer music as well as its potential=
 for making electronic pop. The songs on their debut album Love Comes Clo=
se (2009) have an immediacy that belies thought-provoking titles like The=
 Laurels of Erotomania and The Trees Grew Emotions And Died. In this way =
they mark the transitional moment when synthesizer music went from a subv=
ersive device for sound collagists to a serious commercial force. Live, t=
hey are cerebral and savage, yet sweet and seductive.
> =20
> Thursday, May 10:  Zola Jesus
> Nika Danilova, the woman behind Zola Jesus, brings her epic, iconoclast=
ic sounull of dark evocative beauto the Guggenheim =
rotunda, performing a first time collaboration between Nika and esteemed =
composer JG Thirwell. Thirwell has arranged original compositions penned =
by Danilova to be performed with the Mivos string quartet. Zola Jesus's c=
lassically trained voice is commanding, rich, and silky and her music dra=
ws from industrial, classical, electronic, and experimental rock influenc=
es. =46rom thumping ballads to electronic glitch, no sound goes unexplore=
d. Building on the success of her highly acclaimed album Conatus (2011), =
she has recently collaborated with David Lynch, M83, and Orbital. Zola Je=
sus's live performances have been calleear perfect rainy day =
musiby the Washington Post and onstage she has been described =
by the Independent ahe physical depiction of a dove, of delic=
ate deliverance paired with the strength of determination and purpose fix=
ated in her soundJG Thirwell has worked with Nick Cave, Red Ho=
t Chili Peppers, Bang On a Can, Sonic Youth, Nine Inch Nails, and Kronos =
Quartet, among others.
> =20
> About the Solomon R. Guggenheim =46oundation
> =46ounded in 1937, the Solomon R. Guggenheim =46oundation is dedicated =
to promoting the understanding and appreciation of art, primarily of the =
modern and contemporary periods, through exhibitions, education programs,=
 research initiatives, and publications. Currently the Solomon R. Guggenh=
eim =46oundation owns and operates the Guggenheim Museum on =46ifth Avenu=
e in New York and the Peggy Guggenheim Collection on the Grand Canal in V=
enice, and provides programming and management for the Guggenheim Museum =
Bilbao. The Deutsche Guggenheim in Berlin is the result of a collaboratio=
n, begun in 1997, between the Guggenheim =46oundation and Deutsche Bank. =
The Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, a museum of modern and contemporary art designe=
d by =46rank Gehry on Saadiyat Island, adjacent to the main island of Abu=
 Dhabi city, the capital of the United Arab Emirates, is currently in pro=
gress. More information about the foundation can be found at guggenheim.o=
rg (http://web07.echosentinel.com/web07/l.do=3Fcid=3D60&mid=3D25185&e=3Dl=
vcrat.wvnat=7Etznvy.pbz&t=3D326550&=7Ecid%3D60%26mid%3D25185%26fn%3DLIB12=
0316120103cTav1%2Ehtml%26tn%3D%26ft%3Dstored%26rid%3D1%26mt%3D%26e%3Dlvcr=
at%2Ewvnat%7Etznvy%2Epbz).

ches April 13
> > =20
> > =46eaturing Grouper and Julianna Barwick, Cold Cave, and Zola Jesus i=
n the Museum Rotunda Accompanying the John Chamberlain Retrospective

> >   =20
> > =20
> > (New York, NMarch 19, 2012On April 13, the Gu=
ggenheim will introduce Divine Ricochet (http://web07.echosentinel.com/we=
b07/l.do=3Fcid=3D60&mid=3D25185&e=3Dlvcrat.wvnat=7Etznvy.pbz&t=3D326545&=7E=
cid%3D60%26mid%3D25185%26fn%3DLIB120316120103cTav1%2Ehtml%26tn%3D%26ft%3D=
stored%26rid%3D1%26mt%3D%26e%3Dlvcrat%2Ewvnat%7Etznvy%2Epbz), a three-par=
t series of live music accompanying the John Chamberlain: Choices (http:/=
/web07.echosentinel.com/web07/l.do=3Fcid=3D60&mid=3D25185&e=3Dlvcrat.wvna=
t=7Etznvy.pbz&t=3D326546&=7Ecid%3D60%26mid%3D25185%26fn%3DLIB120316120103=
cTav1%2Ehtml%26tn%3D%26ft%3Dstored%26rid%3D1%26mt%3D%26e%3Dlvcrat%2Ewvnat=
%7Etznvy%2Epbz) retrospective, on view at the museum through May 13, 2012=
.  Produced by Sam Brumbaugh, Special Events Consultant, and Bronwyn Keen=
an, Director of Special Events, the series takes its thematic cue from th=
e poetic fusion, chaotic riffing, explosive color and sublime assemblage =
that characterized Chamberlaiwork. The series title Divine Ri=
cochet is borrowed from a 1991 work by Chamberlain and features the artis=
signature use of wordplay.  A great lover of music, Chamberla=
in pushed boundaries as he explored abstraction, rhythm, harmony, and dis=
sonance, providing a vibrant context for contemporary musical experiments=
 in the Guggenheim rotunda.
> > =20
> > Divine Ricochet (http://web07.echosentinel.com/web07/l.do=3Fcid=3D60&=
mid=3D25185&e=3Dlvcrat.wvnat=7Etznvy.pbz&t=3D326547&=7Ecid%3D60%26mid%3D2=
5185%26fn%3DLIB120316120103cTav1%2Ehtml%26tn%3D%26ft%3Dstored%26rid%3D1%2=
6mt%3D%26e%3Dlvcrat%2Ewvnat%7Etznvy%2Epbz) commences with loops and layer=
ing of voice by Juliana Barwick and Groupesite-specific perfo=
rmance Violet Replacement, comprising long-form ambient pieces on =46rida=
y, April 13; followed by the melodic synthscapes and experimental electro=
-pop of Cold Cave on =46riday, April 27; and then by a one-of-a-kind perf=
ormance of thumping ballads and electronic glitch by the commanding Zola =
Jesus on Thursday, May 10.
> > =20
> > Doors open at 8:30 pm and guests are invited to view the current exhi=
bition John Chamberlain: Choices (http://web07.echosentinel.com/web07/l.d=
o=3Fcid=3D60&mid=3D25185&e=3Dlvcrat.wvnat=7Etznvy.pbz&t=3D326548&=7Ecid%3=
D60%26mid%3D25185%26fn%3DLIB120316120103cTav1%2Ehtml%26tn%3D%26ft%3Dstore=
d%26rid%3D1%26mt%3D%26e%3Dlvcrat%2Ewvnat%7Etznvy%2Epbz) before the perfor=
mances, which start at 10 pm in the museufamed =46rank Lloyd =
Wrighesigned rotunda.
> > =20
> > Tickets
> > Priced at =2427 for nonmembers and =2422 for members, tickets are lim=
ited and available through advanced online ticket sales only at guggenhei=
m.org/ricochet (http://web07.echosentinel.com/web07/l.do=3Fcid=3D60&mid=3D=
25185&e=3Dlvcrat.wvnat=7Etznvy.pbz&t=3D326549&=7Ecid%3D60%26mid%3D25185%2=
6fn%3DLIB120316120103cTav1%2Ehtml%26tn%3D%26ft%3Dstored%26rid%3D1%26mt%3D=
%26e%3Dlvcrat%2Ewvnat%7Etznvy%2Epbz). Grouper and Julianna Barwick ticket=
s will go sale March 20 for members and March 21 for nonmembers. =20
> > =20
> > =46riday, April 13: Grouper and Julianna Barwick
> > Grouper is the solo project of Portland based musician/artist Liz Har=
ris. Since the release of her recently acclaimed album A/A : Alien Observ=
er (2011), Grouper has scored the Sundance favorite The Perception of Mov=
ing Targets, and has been working on projects with both Tiny Vipers and N=
inja Tune producer The Bug (Kevin Martin). Grouper's stately chorded song=
s have been described by Wire magazine aounding as if they'd =
been made against a vast mountainside: voice and instruments-muted piano,=
 spider strummed guitar and growling drone steeped in reverb and delay.=E2Grouper's site-specific Violet Replacement performance in the Gugg=
enheim rotunda will be naturally resonant and comprise long-form ambient =
pieces that include tape loops, field recordings, Wurlitzer loops, and su=
bmerged atmospherics mixed and processed live from an array of dictaphone=
s and tape players.
> > =20
> > Brooklyn-based solo artist Julianna Barwick creates music which is at=
 once orchestral, choral, and meditative, using her voice as an instrumen=
t to create soaring, capacious chants and mystical invocations. Barwick h=
as been compared to the likes of Philip Glass, Brian Eno, Panda Bear, Sta=
rs Of The Lid, and Cocteau Twins. The musician builds multiple loops and =
layers off a single refrain, and State magazine described her live perfor=
mance as composed oordless songs with transporting power=9D where Barwictood alone but sang like a choir of angels.=E2Barwick will open for Grouper on April 13.
> > =20
> > =46riday, April 27: Cold Cave
> > Heirs to the synthpop noir of New Order, Throbbing Gristle, Soft Cell=
, and Muslimgauze, Cold Cave are an experimental electronic pop group fro=
m Philadelphia and New York who make melodic synthscapes with driving bea=
ts. Celebrating the contradictory beauty of the human condition, Cold Cav=
e acknowledges the dark roots of synthesizer music as well as its potenti=
al for making electronic pop. The songs on their debut album Love Comes C=
lose (2009) have an immediacy that belies thought-provoking titles like T=
he Laurels of Erotomania and The Trees Grew Emotions And Died. In this wa=
y they mark the transitional moment when synthesizer music went from a su=
bversive device for sound collagists to a serious commercial force. Live,=
 they are cerebral and savage, yet sweet and seductive.
> > =20
> > Thursday, May 10:  Zola Jesus
> > Nika Danilova, the woman behind Zola Jesus, brings her epic, iconocla=
stic sounull of dark evocative beauto the Guggenhei=
m rotunda, performing a first time collaboration between Nika and esteeme=
d composer JG Thirwell. Thirwell has arranged original compositions penne=
d by Danilova to be performed with the Mivos string quartet. Zola Jesus's=
 classically trained voice is commanding, rich, and silky and her music d=
raws from industrial, classical, electronic, and experimental rock influe=
nces. =46rom thumping ballads to electronic glitch, no sound goes unexplo=
red. Building on the success of her highly acclaimed album Conatus (2011)=
, she has recently collaborated with David Lynch, M83, and Orbital. Zola =
Jesus's live performances have been calleear perfect rainy da=
y musiby the Washington Post and onstage she has been describe=
d by the Independent ahe physical depiction of a dove, of del=
icate deliverance paired with the strength of determination and purpose f=
ixated in her soundJG Thirwell has worked with Nick Cave, Red =
Hot Chili Peppers, Bang On a Can, Sonic Youth, Nine Inch Nails, and Krono=
s Quartet, among others.
> > =20
> > About the Solomon R. Guggenheim =46oundation
> > =46ounded in 1937, the Solomon R. Guggenheim =46oundation is dedicate=
d to promoting the understanding and appreciation of art, primarily of th=
e modern and contemporary periods, through exhibitions, education program=
s, research initiatives, and publications. Currently the Solomon R. Gugge=
nheim =46oundation owns and operates the Guggenheim Museum on =46ifth Ave=
nue in New York and the Peggy Guggenheim Collection on the Grand Canal in=
 Venice, and provides programming and management for the Guggenheim Museu=
m Bilbao. The Deutsche Guggenheim in Berlin is the result of a collaborat=
ion, begun in 1997, between the Guggenheim =46oundation and Deutsche Bank=
. The Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, a museum of modern and contemporary art desig=
ned by =46rank Gehry on Saadiyat Island, adjacent to the main island of A=
bu Dhabi city, the capital of the United Arab Emirates, is currently in p=
rogress. More information about the foundation can be found at guggenheim=
.org (http://web07.echosentinel.com/web07/l.do=3Fcid=3D60&mid=3D25185&e=3D=

From: LambApe <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: quietboy.yuan@gmail.com
Subject: m.guardian.co.uk
http://m.guardian.co.uk/culture/2012/jun/10/slavoj-zizek-humanity-ok-people-=
boring?cat=3Dculture&type=3Darticle

m.guardian.co.uk

Slavok doesn't know the door number of his own apartment in L=
jubljana. "Doesn't matter," he tells the photographer, who wants to pop outs=
ide. "Come back in through the main door, and then just think in terms of po=
litically radical right; you turn from left to right, then at the end, right=
 again." But what's the number, in case he gets lost? "I think it's 20," =C5k suggests. "But who knows? Let's double check." So off he pads d=
own the hallway, opens his door and has a look.
Waving the photographer off, he points in the distance across the Slovenian c=
apital. "Over there, that's a kind of counter-culture establishmen they hate me, I hate them. This is the type of leftists that I hate. Radica=
l leftists whose fathers are all very rich." Most of the other buildings, he=
 adds, are government ministries. "I hate it." Now he's back in the living r=
oom, a clinically tidy little sliver of functional space lacking any discern=
ible aesthetic, the only concessions being a poster for the video game Call O=
f Duty: Black Ops, and a print of Joseph Stalink pours Coke Z=
ero into plastic McDonald's cups decorated in Disney merchandising, but when=
 he opens a kitchen cupboard I see that it's full of clothes.

"I live as a madman!" he exclaims, and leads me on a tour of the apartment t=
o demonstrate why his kitchen cabinets contain only clothing. "You see, ther=
e's no room anywhere else!" And indeed, every other room is lined, floor to c=
eiling, with DVDs and books; volumes of his own 75 works, translated into in=
numerable languages, fill one room alone.

If you have read all ok's work, you are doing better than me=
. Born in 1949, the Slovenian philosopher and cultural critic grew up under T=
ito in the former Yugoslavia, where suspicions of dissidence consigned him t=
o academic backwaters. He came to western attention in 1989 with his first b=
ook written in English, The Sublime Object of Ideology, a re-reading ok's great hero Hegel through the perspective of another hero, the ps=
ychoanalyst Jacques Lacan. Since then there have been titles such as Living i=
n the End Times, along with filmThe Pervert's Guide To Cinema =E2and more articles than I can count.
By the standards of cultural theoryk sits at the more access=
ible end of the spectrubut to give you an idea of where that sti=
ll leaves him, here's a typical quote from a book callek: A G=
uide for the Perplexed, intended to render him more comprehensible:k finds the place for Lacan in Hegel by seeing the Real as the correl=
ate of the self-division and self-doubling within phenomena."
At the risk of upsettink's fanatical global following, I wou=
ld say that a lot of his work is impenetrable. But he writes with exhilarati=
ng ambition and his central thesis offers a perspective even his critics wou=
ld have to concede is thought-provoking. In essence, he argues that nothing i=
s ever what it appears, and contradiction is encoded in almost everything. M=
ost of what we think of as radical or subversivor even simply et=
hicadoesn't actually change anything.

"Like when you buy an organic apple, you're doing it for ideological reasons=
, it makes you feel good: 'I'm doing something for Mother Earth,' and so on.=
 But in what sense are we engaged? It's a false engagement. Paradoxically, w=
e do these things to avoid really doing things. It makes you feel good. You r=
ecycle, you sena month to some Somali orphan, and you did your dut=
y." But really, we've been tricked into operating safety valves that allow t=
he status quo to survive unchallenged? "Yes, exactly." The obsession of west=
ern liberals with identity politics only distracts from class struggle, and w=
hilk doesn't defend any version of communism ever seen in pr=
actice, he remains what he calls a "complicated Marxist" with revolutionary i=
deals.

To his critics, as one memorably put it, he is the Borat of philosophy, chur=
ning out ever more outrageous statements for scandalous effect. "The problem=
 with Hitler was that he was not violent enough," for example, or "I am not h=
uman. I am a monster." Some dismiss him as a silly controversialist; others f=
ear him as an agitator for neo-Marxist totalitarianism. But since the financ=
ial crisis he has been elevated to the status of a global-recession celebrit=
y, drawing crowds of adoring followers who revere him as an intellectual gen=
ius. His popularity is just the sort of paradok delights in b=
ecause if it were down to him, he says, he would rather not talk to anyone.
You wouldn't guess so from the energetic flurry of good manners with which h=
e welcomes us, but he's quick to clarify that his attentiveness is just camo=
uflage for misanthropy. "For me, the idea of hell is the American type of pa=
rties. Or, when they ask me to give a talk, and they say something like, 'Af=
ter the talk there will just be a small receptionI know this is h=
ell. This means all the frustrated idiots, who are not able to ask you a que=
stion at the end of the talk, come to you and, usually, they start: 'Profess=
ok, I know you must be tired, bu' Well, fuck you.=
 If you know that I am tired, why are you asking me? I'm really more and mor=
e becoming Stalinist. Liberals always say about totalitarians that they like=
 humanity, as such, but they have no empathy for concrete people, no? OK, th=
at fits me perfectly. Humanity? Yes, it's Osome great talks, som=
e great arts. Concrete people? No, 99% are boring idiots."

Most of all, he can't stand students. "Absolutely. I was shocked, for exampl=
e, once, a student approached me in the US, when I was still teaching a clas=
which I will never do agaiand he told me: 'You know,=
 professor, it interested me what you were saying yesterday, and I thought, I=
 don't know what my paper should be about. Could you please give me some mor=
e thoughts and then maybe some idea will pop up.' Fuck him! Who I am to do t=
hatk has had to quit most of his teaching posts in Europe and Ame=
rica, to get away from these intolerable students. "I especially hate when t=
hey come to me with personal problems. My standard line is: 'Look at me, loo=
k at my tics, don't you see that I'm mad? How can you even think about askin=
g a mad man like me to help you in personal problems, no?'" You can see what=
 he means, fok cuts a fairly startling physical figur=93 like a grizzly bear, pawing wildly at his face, sniffing and snuffling a=
nd gesticulating between every syllable. "But it doesn't work! They still tr=
ust me. And I hate this becausthis is what I don't like about Am=
erican societI don't like this openness, like when you meet a gu=
y for the first time, and he's starting to tell you about his sex life. I ha=
te this, I hate this!"

I have to laugh at this, becausk brings up his sex life with=
in moments of our first meeting. On the way up in the lift he volunteers tha=
t a former girlfriend used to ask him for what he called "consensual rape". I=
 had imagined he would want to discuss his new book about Hegel, but what he=
 really seems keen to talk about is sex.
"Yeah, because I'm extremely romantic here. You know what is my fear? This p=
ostmodern, permissive, pragmatic etiquette towards sex. It's horrible. They c=
laim sex is healthy; it's good for the heart, for blood circulation, it rela=
xes you. They even go into how kissing is also good because it develops the m=
uscles herthis is horrible, my God!" He's appalled by the promis=
e of dating agencies to "outsource" the risk of romance. "It's no longer tha=
t absolute passion. I like this idea of sex as part of love, you know: 'I'm r=
eady to sell my mother into slavery just to fuck you for ever.' There is som=
ething nice, transcendent, about it. I remain incurably romantic."

I keep thinking I should try to intervene with a question, but he's off agai=
n. "I have strange limits. I am verOK, another detail, fuck it. I=
 was never able to deven if a woman wanted iannal se=
x." Annal sex? "Ah, anal sex. You know why not? Because I couldn't convince m=
yself that she really likes it. I always had this suspicion, what if she onl=
y pretends, to make herself more attractive to me? It's the same thing for f=
ellatio; I was never able to finish into the woman's mouth, because again, m=
y idea is, this is not exactly the most tasteful fluid. What if she's only p=
retending?"

He can count the number of women he has slept with on his hands, because he f=
inds the whole business so nerve-racking. "I cannot have one-night stands. I=
 envy people who can do it; it would be wonderful. I feel nice, let's go, ba=
ng-banyes! But for me, it's something so ridiculously intimate =E2like, my God, it's horrible to be naked in front of another person, y=
ou know? If the other one is evil with a remar'Ha ha, your stoma=
ch,' or whateveeverything can be ruined, you know?" Besides, he c=
an't sleep with anyone unless he believes they might stay together for ever.=
 "All my relationshipthis is why they are very fewer=
e damned from the perspective of eternity. What I mean with this clumsy term=
 is, maybe they will last."

Buk has been divorced three times. How has he coped with tha=
t? "Ah, now I will tell you. You know the young MarI don't ideal=
ise Marx, he was a nasty guy, personallbut he has a wonderful lo=
gic. He says: 'You don't simply dissolve marriage; divorce means that you re=
troactively establish that the love was not the true love.' When love goes a=
way, you retroactively establish that it wasn't even true love." Is that wha=
t he did? "Yes! I erase it totally. I don't only believe that I'm no longer i=
n love. I believe I never was."

As if to illustrate this, he glances at his watch; his 12-year-old son, who l=
ives nearby, will be arriving shortly. How is this going to work when he get=
s here? Don't worryk says, he's bound to be lato=
n account of the tardiness of his mother: "The bitch who claims to have been=
 my wife." But weren't they married? "Unfortunately, yesk has two sonthe other is in his 30but=
 never wanted to be a parent. "I will tell you the formula why I love my two=
 sons. This is my liberal, compassionate side. I cannot resist it, when I se=
e someone hurt, vulnerable and so on. So precisely when the son was not full=
y wanted, this made me want to love him even more."

By now I can see we're not going to get anywhere neak's new b=
ook about Hegel, Less Than Nothing: Hegel and the Shadow of Dialectical Mate=
rialism. Instead, he tells me about the holidays he takes with his young son=
. The last one was to the Burj Al Arab hotel, a grotesque temple to tacky os=
tentation in Dubai. "Why not? Why not? I like to do crazy things. But I did m=
y Marxist duty. I got friendly with the Pakistani taxi driver who showed to m=
e and my son reality. The whole structure of how the workers there live was e=
xplained, how it was controlled. My son was horrified." This summer they are=
 off to Singapore, to an artificial island with swimming pools built on top o=
f 50-storey skyscrapers. "So we can swim there and look down on the city: 'H=
a ha, fuck you.' That's what I like to dtotally crazy things." I=
t wasn't so much fun when his son was younger. "But now, we have a certain r=
hythm established. We sleep 'til one, then we go to breakfast, then we go to=
 the citno culture, just consumerism or some stupid things like t=
hithen we go back for dinner, then we go to a movie theatre, the=
n we play games 'til three in the morning."
I wonder what alk's earnest young followers will make of thi=
s, and worry they will be cross with me for not getting anything more seriou=
s out of him. But tk, Dubai tells us just as much about the w=
orld as a debate about the deficit, say, ever can. When his sweet-looking, p=
olite young son arrives, I try to steek on to the financial c=
risis, and to the role his admirers hope he will play in formulating a radic=
al response.

"I always emphasise: don't expect this from me. I don't think that the task o=
f a guy like me is to propose complete solutions. When people ask me what to=
 do with the economy, what the hell do I know? I think the task of people li=
ke me is not to provide answers but to ask the right questions." He's not ag=
ainst democracy, per se, he just thinks our democratic institutions are no l=
onger capable of controlling global capitalism. "Nice consensual incremental=
 reforms may work, possibly, at a local level." But localism belongs in the s=
ame category as organic apples, and recycling. "It's done to make you feel g=
ood. But the big question today is how to organise to act globally, at an im=
mense international level, without regressing to some authoritarian rule."

How will that happen? "I'm a pessimist in the sense that we are approaching d=
angerous times. But I'm an optimist for exactly the same reason. Pessimism m=
eans things are getting messy. Optimism means these are precisely the times w=
hen change is possible." And what are the chances that things won't change? "=
Ah, if this happens then we are slowly approaching a new apartheid authorita=
rian society. It will not bI must underline thithe o=
ld stupid authoritarianism. This will be a new form, still consumerist." The=
 whole world will look like Dubai? "Yes, and in Dubai, you know, the other s=
ide are literally slaves."

There is something inexplicably touching about alk's mischie=
vous bombast. I hadn't expected him to be so likable, but he really is hilar=
iously good company. I had hoped to find out if he was a genius or a lunaticbut I fear I leave none the wiser. I ask him how seriously he wou=
ld recommend we take him, and he says he would rather be feared than taken f=
or a clown. "Most people think I'm making jokes, exaggeratinbut n=
o, I'm not. It's not that. First I tell jokes, then I'm serious. No, the art=
 is to bring the serious message into the forum of jokes."

Two years ago his front teeth came out. "My son knows I have a good friend; n=
one of us is gay, just good friends. So when he saw me without teeth, he sai=
d: 'I know why.' My son! He was 10! You know what he told me? Think, associa=
te, in the dirtiest way." I think I can guess. "Yes! Sucking! He said my fri=
end complained that my teeth were in the wayk roars with la=
ughter, great gales of paternal pride.

"And you know what was tragicomic? After he told me this, he said: 'Father, d=
id I tell this joke well?'"

A 24-hour launch event for Less Than Nothing takes place on 15 June at Cafe O=
to, London.versobooks.com.=

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: sminfo@fsm.gov.mo
Subject: inquiry about visiting Macau
Dear Sir/Madam,

I have a very specific question regarding applying for Macau visa:

I'm a Chinese citizen (holding Chinese passport), currently working in the
US on US working visa. From September 1st to 4th I'll be on a business trip
to Macau representing my company, however not flying directly to Macau but
through Hong Kong instead. I went to the Chinese Embassy in New York a
couple days ago applying for permit/visa for entering Macau, but the staff
there told me they no longer process applications for Macau visas, and I
was advised to apply for permit on the spot when I'd be entering Macau.

Could you please verify for me if this information was true, namely I, a
Chinese citizen holding US working visa (and returning tickets to the US
through HK), can travel to Macau through Hong Kong and apply for permit to
stay for a total length of 4 days upon arrival at the Macau customs?

Best Regards,

Ko


*Gol Nng, 2015*


From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Yeniu Pan <yeniupan@gmail.com>
Subject: Fwd: inquiry about visiting Macau
---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: *SM INFO* <sminfo@fsm.gov.mo>
Date: Monday, August 17, 2015
Subject: inquiry about visiting Macau
To: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>




Dear Sir / Madam,

This refers to your email inquiring about the visa requirements in Macao.

1.          Holders of a valid Chinese passport with a valid residence
document or visa of a third country or region are entitled to visa-free
transit through Macao and * 7-day *Authorization to Stay. In other words,
they do not need to apply for an entry visa to come to Macao.

2.          Our immigration officers at the border checkpoint check the
visitorresidence document or visa of a third country or region. =
Visitors
who do not meet the requirements can be refused entry to Macao.

3.          If you have any further inquiries, please visit our website at
http://www.fsm.gov.mo/psp/eng/Service_Imm.html or call the Subdivision belo=
w
for inquiry.

Subdivision at Macao International Airport Checkpoint         Tel: (853)
8898 1317

Subdivision at Hong Kong-Macao Ferry Terminal Checkpoint      Tel:(853)
8798 5327

Subdivision at Border Gate Checkpoint
Tel:(853) 8980 0321

Best regards,

Macao Immigration Department
------------------------------
:* Yuan Gao [quietboy.yuan@gmail.com
<javascript:_e(%7B%7D,'cvml','quietboy.yuan@gmail.com');>]
:* Friday, 14 August, 2015 2:59
:* SM INFO
:* inquiry about visiting Macau

Dear Sir/Madam,

I have a very specific question regarding applying for Macau visa:

I'm a Chinese citizen (holding Chinese passport), currently working in the
US on US working visa. From September 1st to 4th I'll be on a business trip
to Macau representing my company, however not flying directly to Macau but
through Hong Kong instead. I went to the Chinese Embassy in New York a
couple days ago applying for permit/visa for entering Macau, but the staff
there told me they no longer process applications for Macau visas, and I
was advised to apply for permit on the spot when I'd be entering Macau.

Could you please verify for me if this information was true, namely I, a
Chinese citizen holding US working visa (and returning tickets to the US
through HK), can travel to Macau through Hong Kong and apply for permit to
stay for a total length of 4 days upon arrival at the Macau customs?

Best Regards,

Ko

> I would like invite you to participate in an on-site interview with Amazon
> within the next several weeks. Please provide me with several dates you can
> be available.  Once we have determined a date, I will commence with
> scheduling your trip and send you an email with details to help prepare you
> for your interviews.  ****
>
> To schedule your interviews and travel, please respond to the following: *
> ***
>
>    1. Several dates that you are available to interview (please provide
>    at least 4) ****
>    2. If you are not local to Seattle we will also need:
>    A.  The airport you will be flying out of, if applicable
>    B.  The times you would prefer to fly in and out of Seattle (please be
>    specific if you have needs we should be sensitive to)
>    C.  How your name appears on your personal I.D. (please break out
>    first, middle (if applicable), and last name)
>    *Please Note: We are happy to provide a two-night stay while you are
>    interviewing with us if you are traveling from outside the Seattle area.
>    * ****
>    3. Country of origin****
>    4. Graduate date****
>    5. Any other upcoming interviews/offer deadlines **Please note: You
>    may NOT continue the interview process with Amazon if you have already
>    accepted an offer from another company******
>    6. Current cell phone number.****
>
> ** **
>
> If you require coast to coast travel, we recommend traveling the day
> before your interview date and leaving the day after your interviews (ex:
> fly to Seattle on Sunday, interview Monday, depart Tuesday morning).****
>
> Please Note that interviews often last five - eight hours and include
> walking to and from different buildings - many of which are dog friendly.
> Please let me know in advance if you require any accommodations or have
> special dietary requests. ****
>

> interviews.  Many thanks and I look forward to your reply!

> Sue

>
> Here is what we will need for the Management company:
>
> We need to check credit, please e-mail me the following information.
>  Typically the better your credit the less documents I need
> If credit is good, for instance, we can use pay stubs or copy of a bank
> statement or employment letter, won't need everything if credit is good
> The lower the credit, then you will need a,b,c
>
>
> Sue
>
> 1)  Full name
> 2)  SS#
> 3)  Date of birth
> 4)  Current address
> We  will need you to fax or e-mail us:
> a)  Letter of employment stating annual income
> b)  Copies of last two pay stubs
> c)  Last year's W2

> rent and  one month security deposit.

> guarantor .The  formula is that combined annual income should be 40 times

From: <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Ruby <ruby@efulgent.net>
Subject: Re: Congratulation!!!!
Hello Ruby,

Thanks for all your efforts! I have several simple questions I wish you
could help me with, after reading the offer letter:

!. Would the company help me file my H1B application as soon as the program
is starting in the year 2013? If yes, will this be formally written in the
contract, i.e. as a provision of the contract?

2. The salary per annum ranges from 60k to 65k. I just wanna know what
would make it 65k for me :P

3. Would there be any vacation once I start working for the client? The
reason I ask this is because I haven't been back to China for quite a long
time, and I hope I can take a short vacation for that purpose in year 2013.

4. If I were to work for a local client in Phoenix, what's the
accommodation the company offers like?

So far these are the questions that concern me most. Thanks for your time
and patience!

Best,

Yuan Gao

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: mail3@facerecords.com
Subject: My bid for the Toru Takemitsu vinyl...
Hello,

I just bid on the <TORU TAKEMITSU SEIJI OZAWA NOVEMBER STEPS RCA RX-2355
Japanese pressing Vinyl LP> sold by your store from eBay, and paid in
haste, till I saw your claim that you couldn't ship it to US for $4...

I was frozen a bit, and thought I might still pay for the overhead.
However... I've decided I really can't accept the $18.5 shipping fee you
proposed on eBay... I know the fault is all mine, but now I think you might
have to cancel the transaction...

So sorry for all the inconvenience I've caused you.

Best regards,

K.Y.

From: <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: "Farley, Ben" <farleyb@amazon.com>
Subject: Re: Amazon Phone screen document
import java.util.*;

public static int[] common(int[] array1, int[] array2)
{
    HashSet<Integer> set = new HashSet<>();

    for (int i : array1)
        set.add(i);

    for (int i : array2)
        if (set.!contains(i))
            set.remove(i);

    return set.toArray();
}

On Mon, Mar 25, 2013 at 12:22 PM, Yeniu Pan <yeniupan@gmail.com> wrote:

> LOGOS
>
> The logo mark is inspired by the form of exclamation mark. The concept
> behind this logo mark is to indicate the strong feeling of bursting with
> inspiration.
> Therefore, instead of taking the exclamation mark shape, it is also shape=
d
> like a light bulb, which presents the concept of "idea".
> The logo type was hand drew carefully to indicate the concept of "being
> creative" and the logo mark becomes part of the word "did" to emphasis th=
e
> "creative action".
> The final logo is developed into both print and web version by using
> different type treatment but in the same type lockup. The print version o=
f
> logo is more crafty but the web version is more
> digitally presented.
>
>
> COLORS
>
> The purpose of choosing high contrast color: black and bright yellow is t=
o
> indicate the active thinking process and the "brilliant idea".
>
> POSTERS
> The posters have two parts which also indicate two different usages based
> on the concept of both prints and web. One poster is made for the purpose
> of web promotion.
> The other two are made for "the opening event exhibition". The purpose of
> making the exhibition is to encourage more people to join the "this is wh=
at
> I did today"'s creative social media group, get inspired and start to
> think/do something creative. The exhibition will have 20 best projects fr=
om
> 2012 which selected from "this is what i did today" website and featured =
in
> the exhibition in New York.
>
> WEB
> "This is what I did today" social net working website plays the important
> role of entire campaign. This website is a key media to promoting "be
> creative everyday" idea and also connecting people to get inspired by eac=
h
> other. The difference between "this is what I did today" and other social
> networking site is the rule of "original creation". "This is what I did
> today" requires user to interact online by posting their own creative wor=
ks
> or sharing their own creative thoughts. The purpose of making this site i=
s
> not retweeting/sharing good works from other resources, but creating and
> sharing your own work. The work from your own doesn't have to be a "maste=
r
> piece", but has to be "something different than you use to do". The missi=
on
> of this site is encouraging user to have their own daily creative practic=
e
> in order to think or do something outside of the box.
>
> The entire site is designed and functioned as a calendar, which connect
> with the concept of "everyday practice".
>
> IPHONE APP
>
> The iPhone app is structured and based on the function of website. It
> gives the quick access to post and connect with other users.
>
> --
> NIU NIU*.* *P*
>

Subject: Need to press five titles
Hello,

I have 5 titles to press, 500 copies each.

Specs:
- 12"
- Lacquer cutting: approximately 20 minutes per side
- Test pressing
- 130g CLEAR TRANSLUCENT vinyl with CLEAR plastic (transparent) jackets
- White labels with black text
- Stickers, text, on jacket

My time is pressing, has to be ready by mid Sep. Please give me the quotes,
including all setup charges (I provide CD-ready master files).

Thanks!

Juan

Subject: vinyl printing inquiry
Hello,

I called earlier today, my name is Juan, phone number is 656-688-8554.

I'm planning to release several titles in vinyl in the next few months. I'd
like to know how the manufacturing fee adds up.

Requirements are:
- clear plastic sleeve OR white paper sleeve
- clear & color vinyl disc
- normal weight

And, can I be scheduled to visit your office and factory within this week,
so I can get a clear image of how things work?

Best,

Juan

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: sales@eksmfg.com
Subject: vinyl printing inquiry
Hello,

I'm planning to release several titles in vinyl in the next few months. I'd
like to know how the manufacturing fee adds up.

Requirements are:
- clear plastic sleeve OR white paper sleeve
- clear & color vinyl disc
- normal weight

And, can I be scheduled to visit your office and factory within this week,
so I can get a clear image of how things work?

Best,

Yuan Gao

From: <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Ancy@nawlaw.com
Subject: Inquiring about OPT extension
Dear Ancy,

This is Yuan Gao, a friend of one of your recent clients named Yeniu Pan. I
have some questions regarding my Optional Practical Training, and Pan said
I should seek help from you.

Briefly, my situation is as follows: I graduated from Columbia University
on December 2011, with a Master's degree in Electrical Engineering. My OPT
status began on Feb 1st 2012, and would be valid till Jan 31st 2013. Right
now I'm still unemployed.

I'm aware that for STEM degree holders there's a 17-month OPT extension,
provided that the person is employed. So my question would be: Can you help
me in some way to get my OPT extension under the current situation? If yes,
I'd like to make an appointment with you.

BTW, Yeniu Pan wants me tell you that she has passed her visa interview.


Best regards,

Yuan Gao


From: <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Ancy Varghese <Ancy@nawlaw.com>
Subject: Re: Inquiring about OPT extension
Ancy,

Yes, I'd love to make an appointment now. What's the earliest time
available next week? And, may I know how much do you charge?

Thank you.

>

> E-Verify. I suggest you make an appointment to come to our office so that
> we can discuss extension of OPT or other options you may have to extend
> your stay in the ****U.S.**** ****

From: None
To: None
Subject: None
Hello Ancy,

Lately I'm preparing to go back to school, applying for a program in NYU.
Since currently I'm holding H1B, if I'm admitted, I'll have to transfer my
H1B to F1. I'm hoping you can help me out with the visa transfer process.

But first of all, can you tell me, in general, how long the whole procedure
normally takes to transfer from H1B to F1, provided the applicant (me) is
living in the US?

Thank you.

Gao, Yuan

H1B to F1. I'm hoping you can help me out with the visa transfer process.

Thank you.

Gao, Yuan

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Midori L Yasuda <midori.yasuda@nyu.edu>
Subject: Re: application for Tisch ITP
Hi Midori,

Thanks for your effort. I've just learned about the fact that, if my
full-time job can be maintained while being enrolled in a full-time
program, one can study without changing the status from H1B to F1, which
happens to be my case here.

I'm thinking, is it possible for you to put me on a wait list for Fall
2013, and see if there will be any vacancy showing up later?

Best,

Yuan

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Dajuin Yao <dajuin@gmail.com>
Subject:

Omg, I skimmed this, and felt like... that we Chinese are still gripped in
the hands of the whites, tighter than ever.

Are we Chinese really unable to see who we are if without seeing our own
reflections from the cognition/recognition of the whites?

"Can we identify a specific Chinese sounds?" Sounds like a significant
question asking for deep insights... but unfortunately naive and arrogant.

We welcome "scholars from all disciplines to explore 'sounds & noise' in
China." Apparently the only way to save us Chinese from our lack of
sound-wise sophistication and inadequacy is for us to readily adopt their
established modes of narratives, to embrace their ideologies... such that
one of the greatest outcomes is that they can be provided "with new
perspectives on and a new understanding of China." How ambitious, how
promising!

This is utterly awkward... I don't know. I must be forgiven if I just
missed the point from tip to toe. You were right that I was tripping last
night after your emails, and I couldn't get a sec's sleep since then and
feel like shit right now...

Best,

Yuan

> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> From: Wenhua Shi <wshi@colgate.edu>
> Date: Sun, Jun 9, 2013 at 8:00 PM
> Subject: Fwd: MCLC: Soundscapes in Contemporary China--cfp
> To: Dajuin Yao <dajuin@gmail.com>
>
>
>
>
> Sent from my iPhone
>
> Begin forwarded message:
>
> From: Jiayun <jiayunzhuang@gmail.com>
> Date: June 8, 2013 12:53:44 PM EDT
> To: Wenhua Shi <wshi@colgate.edu>
> Subject: Fwd: MCLC: Soundscapes in Contemporary China--cfp
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Begin forwarded message:
>
> From: "Denton, Kirk" <denton.2@osu.edu>
> Date: June 8, 2013, 21:28:12 GMT+08:00
> To: "mclc@lists.service.ohio-state.edu" <mclc@lists.service.ohio-state.ed=
u
> >
> Subject: MCLC: Soundscapes in Contemporary China--cfp
>
> MCLC LIST
> From: Andreas Steen <ostas@hum.au.dk>
> Subject: Soundscapes in Contemporary China--cfp
> ***********************************************************
>
> CALL FOR PAPERS
>
> Aarhus University, Denmark / CHIME, 21-24 August, 2014
> Sound, Noise and the Everyday =96 Soundscapes in Contemporary China
>
> China is filled with sounds; indeed, some people would say that it is a
> noisy place. Some sounds immediately come to mind, for example those of
> music, radio and TV broadcasts, along with blaring loudspeakers, public
> announcements and street conversations, or speech/language and
> communication more generally. Some types or notions of sound may be
> difficult to grasp or to categorize, for example the sound of a city,
> sounds of progress, sounds of revolution or sounds of change. ~
> Sounds may be deliberately produced (and manipulated), or may be brought
> forth unintentionally, and they can be direct and physical or indirect an=
d
> abstract (or both at the same time). To all events, sounds appear
> everywhere, with a variety of different intentions and meanings; the same
> can be said for noise and silence.
>
> Aarhus University and CHIME invite scholars from all disciplines to
> explore 'sounds & noise' in China. This conference (featuring for CHIME a=
s
> its 18th International Meeting) does not focus on any particular
> historical period or research methodology, but seeks for the first time t=
o
> bring scholars together who share an interest in aspects related to sound=
.
>
> Can we identify a specific Chinese sound? If so, where are the roots to b=
e
> found, and how did this sound achieve its current form? Sound production,
> associations and entanglements, meanings and (listening) effects as well
> as issues of promotion, manipulation and elimination will be discussed in
> relation to Chinese history, culture, society and politics.
>
> The broader aim of this conference is to establish 'sound' as an
> analytical category that provides us with new perspectives on and a new
> understanding of China.
>
> The publication of a conference volume is planned.
>
> Possible topics include:
> Sound Production, Sound Control
> Sound and the State
> Sound and Music
> Eliminating Noise, Producing Sound
> Defining Urban Soundscapes
> Defining Rural Soundscapes
> Chinese Sounds, Foreign Sounds
> Sounds in Chinese History (or Society)
> Sound and the Everyday
>
> Abstracts of around 300 words are invited for twenty-minute presentations
> on the conference theme. Proposers may also submit panel sessions of a
> maximum of 120 minutes (including discussion). In this case, an abstract
> of around 300 words should detail the focus of the panel as a whole, with
> abstracts of 100-200 words for each contribution. We will also support a
> number of poster sessions in the course of the conference, enabling work
> in progress to be shared using video/image as well as other media. A brie=
f
> description of the material and technical requirements should be submitte=
d
> for this.
>
> The deadline for submission of abstracts is February 16, 2014. An early
> acceptance policy will be implemented for those in need of conference
> confirmation for grant or visa applications. Papers and (especially)
> panels addressing the theme of the conference (while referring to
> sufficiently specific research) are explicitly encouraged. All abstracts
> should be forwarded to: [ostas@hum.au.dk]
>
> A conference web-page with further information will be organized in Fall
> 2013.
>
> For further information please contact:
> Aarhus University
> Andreas Steen, Associate Professor, email: ostas@hum.au.dk
> Tel. +45-87162375.
>
> CHIME
> Frank Kouwenhoven, email: chime@wxs.nl
> Tel. +31-71-5133123 or 5133794, Mob. 06-4029.3426~
>
>
> SINCE THIS MESSAGE WILL BE TRANSFERRED THROUGH DIFFERENT CHANNELS WE
> APOLOGIZE BEFOREHAND FOR DOUBLE-DELIVERY AND CROSS-POSTING!
>
> Andreas Steen
> Associate Professor
> Asian Studies
> Institute for Culture and Society
> Aarhus University
> Bldg. 1465, r. 318
> Jens Chr. Skous Vej 7
> 8000 Aarhus C
> Tel.: +45-87162375
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> MCLC mailing list
> MCLC@lists.service.ohio-state.edu
> https://lists.service.ohio-state.edu/mailman/listinfo/mclc
>

>> Begin forwarded message:
>>
>> From: "Denton, Kirk" <denton.2@osu.edu>
>> Date: June 8, 2013, 21:28:12 GMT+08:00
>> To: "mclc@lists.service.ohio-state.edu" <
>> mclc@lists.service.ohio-state.edu>
>> Subject: MCLC: Soundscapes in Contemporary China--cfp
>>
>> MCLC LIST
>> From: Andreas Steen <ostas@hum.au.dk>
>> Subject: Soundscapes in Contemporary China--cfp
>> ***********************************************************
>>
>> CALL FOR PAPERS
>>
>> Aarhus University, Denmark / CHIME, 21-24 August, 2014
>> Sound, Noise and the Everyday =96 Soundscapes in Contemporary China
>>
>> China is filled with sounds; indeed, some people would say that it is a
>> noisy place. Some sounds immediately come to mind, for example those of
>> music, radio and TV broadcasts, along with blaring loudspeakers, public
>> announcements and street conversations, or speech/language and
>> communication more generally. Some types or notions of sound may be
>> difficult to grasp or to categorize, for example the sound of a city,
>> sounds of progress, sounds of revolution or sounds of change. ~
>> Sounds may be deliberately produced (and manipulated), or may be brought
>> forth unintentionally, and they can be direct and physical or indirect a=
nd
>> abstract (or both at the same time). To all events, sounds appear
>> everywhere, with a variety of different intentions and meanings; the sam=
e
>> can be said for noise and silence.
>>
>> Aarhus University and CHIME invite scholars from all disciplines to
>> explore 'sounds & noise' in China. This conference (featuring for CHIME =
as
>> its 18th International Meeting) does not focus on any particular
>> historical period or research methodology, but seeks for the first time =
to
>> bring scholars together who share an interest in aspects related to soun=
d.
>>
>> Can we identify a specific Chinese sound? If so, where are the roots to =
be
>> found, and how did this sound achieve its current form? Sound production=
,
>> associations and entanglements, meanings and (listening) effects as well
>> as issues of promotion, manipulation and elimination will be discussed i=
n
>> relation to Chinese history, culture, society and politics.
>>
>> The broader aim of this conference is to establish 'sound' as an
>> analytical category that provides us with new perspectives on and a new
>> understanding of China.
>>
>> The publication of a conference volume is planned.
>>
>> Possible topics include:
>> Sound Production, Sound Control
>> Sound and the State
>> Sound and Music
>> Eliminating Noise, Producing Sound
>> Defining Urban Soundscapes
>> Defining Rural Soundscapes
>> Chinese Sounds, Foreign Sounds
>> Sounds in Chinese History (or Society)
>> Sound and the Everyday
>>
>> Abstracts of around 300 words are invited for twenty-minute presentation=
s
>> on the conference theme. Proposers may also submit panel sessions of a
>> maximum of 120 minutes (including discussion). In this case, an abstract
>> of around 300 words should detail the focus of the panel as a whole, wit=
h
>> abstracts of 100-200 words for each contribution. We will also support a
>> number of poster sessions in the course of the conference, enabling work
>> in progress to be shared using video/image as well as other media. A bri=
ef
>> description of the material and technical requirements should be submitt=
ed
>> for this.
>>
>> The deadline for submission of abstracts is February 16, 2014. An early
>> acceptance policy will be implemented for those in need of conference
>> confirmation for grant or visa applications. Papers and (especially)
>> panels addressing the theme of the conference (while referring to
>> sufficiently specific research) are explicitly encouraged. All abstracts
>> should be forwarded to: [ostas@hum.au.dk]
>>
>> A conference web-page with further information will be organized in Fall
>> 2013.
>>
>> For further information please contact:
>> Aarhus University
>> Andreas Steen, Associate Professor, email: ostas@hum.au.dk
>> Tel. +45-87162375.
>>
>> CHIME
>> Frank Kouwenhoven, email: chime@wxs.nl
>> Tel. +31-71-5133123 or 5133794, Mob. 06-4029.3426~
>>
>>
>> SINCE THIS MESSAGE WILL BE TRANSFERRED THROUGH DIFFERENT CHANNELS WE
>> APOLOGIZE BEFOREHAND FOR DOUBLE-DELIVERY AND CROSS-POSTING!
>>
>> Andreas Steen
>> Associate Professor
>> Asian Studies
>> Institute for Culture and Society
>> Aarhus University
>> Bldg. 1465, r. 318
>> Jens Chr. Skous Vej 7
>> 8000 Aarhus C
>> Tel.: +45-87162375
>>
>>
>> _______________________________________________
>> MCLC mailing list
>> MCLC@lists.service.ohio-state.edu
>> https://lists.service.ohio-state.edu/mailman/listinfo/mclc
>>
>
>

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Dajuin Yao <dajuin@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: Sound Art China SH
Dear DJ,

Namaste.

As I gather, SAC SH is at present your top priority and a full load. A good
opportunity tho, as you put it, for us to make use of the resources at
hand, your fundings and the yet-to-be-exploited musical facilities
in-and-around New York at this side.

Pressing def. be done in US, and I'll research hard to see if Discmakers
measures up or if better options exist. This better be settled prior to the
selection of titles and post-production. (Since 5/6 titles are readily
available, this could be considered executed, plus the propective of
emerging materials to be added with the unfolding of SAC SH.)

Once the pressing biz and money in order, we can start working on the
promotional and distributional details in the mean time. Ideal scenario:
When the titles are freshly hatched they could be sent to the reassuring
hands of our distributing partners (physical & online stores) in no time,
with all the ads & peer reviews in place.

I also envision the yet-to-be-revived Chinese New Ear would
ideally function as an aggregated site of all these acts for sensational
effects (on steroids, as you planned), including follow-ups of the latest
releases/performances/exhibitions, and/or digestions of new theories and
publications regarding the making/consuming of sound art of all sorts in
China. Even newsletters for ppl to subscribe to~ (I can also take
charge of ancillary Twitter/Tumblr/Facebook IDs in comply with the
despicable Geist of SSN.)

That's the general annotations I can think of for the moment. Within this
week I'm still up to hunting for a new apt to share with GX. (Promise's
promise=85besides it lightens burden of rent.) After moved-in I will get in=
to
contact with the CD/LP pressing entities ASAP. I anticipate this be done
before July ends.

Let me know if anything missing.

My regards to you, your mom, and Ma Nan.

Yuan
(lately I just introduce myself as "Juan", works pretty well.)


On Tuesday, July 2, 2013, Dajuin Yao wrote:

> Dear Gao Yuan,
>
> Thanks for your offer of support and help. I think this might be a
> great beginning for both of us on many fronts, while we do other
> project at the same time.
>
> Let me explain a bit. Sound Art China (SAC) Shanghai has good funding.
> There are 3 parts of this event: A: Sound installation show; B: sound
> art archive, including publication; C: live performance.
>
> the second part will include a new site of complete data (even sound)
> on chinese sound art. pretty much like a ChineseNewEar site on
> steroids. i might even revive the domain name and just use
> ChineseNewEar.net.  Site will be in both chinese and english.  As much
> sound clips as ppl willing to put on it.
>
> BTW, i've got a team of over a dozen students on this project, but
> most of them, as you can guess, are useless and the time it takes to
> train them is not worth bothering.
>
> that part also includes publication/releases. Now with your help --
> you can be the international producer of this Post-Concrete business
> -- i plan to release a series of CDs/LPs, such as WCC KLONE Concert,
> my Dream Reverberations, Samson's works, Xu Cheng's new live work,
> etc.  All the pressing, although can be done in China for cheaper, but
> once pressed in CHina, it'll be hard to ship them out for intl
> release. So, best is pressed in the US, and put the stock in U.S. This
> we need your help and maybe hire someone to do it.
>
> Funding should be okay for this year, say if we plan on 5 or 6 good
> solid titles. And now we need to do promotion after the goods are
> manufactured. Promotion is something we can both work on together and
> there's a lot of work in this area.
>
> So it seem that Discmakers.com is a good place to work with pressing.
> I've use them twice. Maybe you can find better (closer) plants with
> more personal touch in production process, that would be best.
> Discmakers also do vinyl and it's reasonable price, and i really like
> the color translucent vinyls. These should sell very very well in the
> West.
>
> The whole thing about the CD/Vinyl business is to keep the good
> moving, shipping, circulating.
>
> If you're fine with the plan, let's get it going ~! and tell me your
> other ideas.
>
> best,
>
> Dajuin
>

Dear Sir/Madam,

I have 5 titles to press, 500 copies each. My time is tight. A small amount
of each title (~10=9620) needs to be sent to China by air to meet the
deadline of an exhibition by Oct 10. <x-apple-data-detectors://7> The
remaining copies will be sent to New York. Please let me know if it's
possible for you to meet the deadline, then I'll send you the specs and ask
for a quote (I provide CD-ready master files).

Yuan G.

> Internships and Jobs in the Arts - December 12, 2013
>
> **********************************************************
> INDEX
> **********************************************************
>
> INTERNSHIPS
>
> 1. Various Internships, Women Make Movies
>
> 2. Office Intern, ArtTable
>
> 3. Gallery Intern, Marlborough Chelsea

> 4. Director's Office Intern, Whitebox Art Center

> 5. Assistant Director, Exhibition and Program Funding | Development, MOMA

> 6. Communications Associate, The Royal Oak Foundation

> 7. Teaching Artist, Artistic Noise

> 8. Director, Cathy and Jesse Marion Art Gallery at SUNY Fredonia

> 9. Part-Time Assistant, Jewelry Business
>
> **********************************************************
> INTERNSHIPS
> **********************************************************
>
> 1. Various Internships, Women Make Movies
> Location: New York, NY
> Term: Spring 2014
>
> Exciting opportunity to learn about independent and documentary film
> distribution at Women Make Movies!
> We have immediate internships available i> - Marketing
> - Filmmaker Services
> - Workshop Series
> - Distribution
> - Administration
>
> Established in 1972 to address the under representation and
> misrepresentation of women in the media industry, Women Make Movies is a
> multicultural, multiracial, non-profit media arts organization which
> facilitates the production, promotion, distribution and exhibition of
> independent films and videotapes by and about women. The organization
> provides services to both users and makers of film and video programs, wi=
th
> a special emphasis on supporting work by women of color. Women Make Movie=
s
> facilitates the development of feminist media through an internationally
> recognized Distribution Service and a Production Assistance Program.
>
> Applications for internships are accepted year-round.
> Interns work a minimum of 15 hours per week.
>
> WMM Interns receive:
> - Local travel reimbursement
> - Free workshop attendance
> - Free access to screen titles from the Women Make Movies collection
> - College or University course credit
>
> For an application, please visit http://www.wmm.com/about/jobs.shtml
>
> For questions, contact: jobs@wmm.com
>
> **********************************************************
>
> 2. Office Intern, ArtTable
> Location: New York, NY
> Term: Spring 2014
>
> While we do tailor each intern's experience to her interests and skills,
> there are a few general ways in which our interns help up. Interns work
> directly with ArtTable's Executive Director, Marketing and Development
> Manager, Communications and Special Events Manager, and Regional
> Programming Coordinator. The Intern will:
> - Conduct research, collect and compile data, and create reports for
> various initiatives, programs and archival purposes through surveys and
> analysis of previous data and materials.
> - Assist staff in a variety of administrative tasks including attendance
> at events, mailings, outreach to members, filing, office management and
> data entry.
> - The weekly commitment would be 2 days a week from 10-6, but we are
> flexible
>
> Required Skills:
> - An interest in arts administration and knowledge of the art world
> - Strong knowledge of Microsoft Office, especially Excel
> - Previous administrative experience
> - Good interpersonal skills
>
> This position will be for academic credit. To apply, please send a cover
> letter and resume to Evelyn Bround at ebround@arttable.org.
>
> **********************************************************
>
> 3. Gallery Intern, Marlborough Chelsea
> Location: New York, NY
> Term: Spring 2014
>
> Marlborough Chelsea
> 545 West 25th Street
> New York, NY 10001
> Hours of Operation: TueSat 10a6pm
>
> Marlborough Chelsea is seeking a part time intern to work closely with
> Directors and gallery staff supporting all daily gallery operations.
>
> RESPONSIBILITIES:
> The positioresponsibilities include, but are not limited, to =
the
> following:
> - Greet all gallery visitors and answer general questions
> - Assist Archivist with inventory, imaging, and press requests
> - Provide director support, including booking appointments, scheduling
> travel arrangements, and general correspondence
> - Follow up and research all relevant auctions
>
> REQUIREMENTS:
> - Fluent in Office/Word/Outlook/Excel, and web research; experience with
> gallery based inventory software.

> 7. Teaching Artist, Artistic Noise
> Location: New York, NY
>
> About Artistic Noise:
> Artistic Noise is an arts and entrepreneurship program for youth involved
> in the juvenile justice system. By working both inside the detention
> facility and back in the community, Artistic Noise provides continuity fo=
r
> youth who are often experiencing trauma and upheaval in their lives. In
> Artistic Noise participants process and document their lives by creating
> artwork exploring themes such as identity, hope, incarceration, and dream=
s.
> Participants exhibit and market their artwork, learning transferable job
> and life skills from entrepreneurial projects and exhibit planning.
>
> About new Teaching Artist position:
> Artistic Noise has partnered with the New York City Department of
> Probation for two years on an innovative Art Therapy program for youth
> involved in the juvenile justice system. The Artistic Noise Teaching Arti=
st
> will co-facilitate workshops with an Art Therapist focusing on Artistic
> Noisrestorative justice and positive youth development models=

> workshops will be held in the Brooklyn on Thursdays from 4:30-6:00 for
> youth ages 14-16 involved with the juvenile justice system. We are lookin=
g
