> is the possibility of additional workshops as well with times and locatio=
ns
> to be determined at a later date.

> - You must be available to teach on Thursday afternoons from 4:30-6:00 in

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Yeniu Pan <yeniupan@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: Wedding speech. Need it before Sunday.
Yuanyuan is one of my best friends in this country. We immediately clicked
with each other the first time we met. I think it is callehe meant=
 to
b. John, please dobe jealous. ;-p


I remember that, a few years ago, when Yuanyuan had just started dating
John, they were both leading a somewhat unsettled life. Both unemployed at
the time, with little money at their disposal, yet being with each other
had provided them with such happiness. Yes, happiness is the key to an
indissoluble bond between lovers. However, a relationship always meet with
looming challenges that threaten to snatch that happiness away. Indeed, by
the time they moved in together, their relationship had been facing some
difficulties following their new life. But Yuanyuan was an excellent
problem solver. She faced up the problems with John, and by effective
communication they strived for and succeeded in reaching mutual
understanding, which had blessed their relationship with a promising future=
.


If you want to truly understand Yuanyuan, you need to really know her well.
She appears tough, and seems to be always in control of things. In fact,
what's inside of her is soft, sensitive, sometimes insecure,
and occasionally pessimistic. I think that's a big reason she chose John as
her life partner, that he would always give her comfort, appease her
insecurity, and the most important point being that he's the man who truly
knows and understands her.


Now, my lovely BFF is here, in her gorgeous wedding dress, with the man she
truly loves. After conquering all the troubles, hand in hand, they had
completed each other and arrived at this moment of perfectness.
Relationship is not only about love and passion, but also understanding,
compromising, and sacrificing, all of which had brought Yuanyuan and John
where they are today.


Congratulations my dear, your happiness has just started!


Nfinally=A1Ahappy endinC

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>

DJ,

I think we should hold up releasing vinyls till we find a better spot. The

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Martin Labrosse <martin@mobineko.com>
Date: Mon, Sep 9, 2013 at 9:00 PM
Subject: Mobineko Client Services (int)
To: quietboy.yuan@gmail.com


Hi Yuan,

Thanks for contacting us.  There would be 2 issues with your request.  The
first would be the turnaround time.  4 weeks would really not be possible
for us to turnaround a rush vinyl order. 5~6 weeks we could manage, but 4
weeks simply can't be done.  The next issue would be with the portion
shipped to China.  Every Chinese customer who has ordered vinyl from us has
had tremendous problems with Chinese customs and in most cases the
shipments were never delivered as Chinese customs requested extremely
import duties and in some cases the parcels were seized due to the audio
content not being allowed.  In other words, shipping to China is not
advisable. We could ship to Taiwan if you would have a way of picking up
the parcels, but that can be a hassle for you.

Our apologies for not being able to do much here.  If you have more time to
allow for a rush turnaround of 5~6 weeks and a US/Europe delivery address,
we could do something.

Kind regards
Martin

-- 

+886 4 2202 3065 ext. 5027
+44 207 193 7678 ext. 5027
---
Mobineko - CD - Vinyl - Print Manufacturing

UK tel: 0203 193 9959  (FREEPHONE)
UK Order Processing: Floor 5, Amphenol Business Complex, Thanet Way, Kent,
CT5 3JF

TW tel: +886 4 2202 3065
B1 no. 6, 119 Zhong Tai East Road, Taichung City, Taiwan

join us on Facebook for latest news, features and specials:
http://www.facebook.com/pages/**Mobineko/110281649046189<http://www.facebook.com/pages/Mobineko/110281649046189>

Subject: Ask about delivery time
Dear Sir/Madam,

I have 5 titles to press, 500 copies each. My time is tight. A small amount
of each title (~10=9620) needs to be sent to China by air to meet the
deadline of an exhibition by Oct 10. <x-apple-data-detectors://7> The
remaining copies will be sent to New York. Please let me know if it's
possible for you to meet the deadline, then I'll send you the specs and ask
for a quote (I provide CD-ready master files).

Best,

Yuan G.

> School of Visual Arts (SVA) *The American Algorists: Linear Sublime*
>
> October 2ovember 27, 2013
>
> *SVA Flatiron Gallery
> *133/141 West 21st Street
> New York City
> *Hours*: Mondariday 9apm, Saturday,10apm=
; closed on Sundays and
> public holidays
>
> *Panel Discussion:* Saturday, November 9, 2ppm, Room 101C
> *Reception:* Saturday, November 9, pm
>
> www.sva.edu<http://interspire.e-flux.com/link.php?M=3D287760&N=3D6959&L=
=3D1266&F=3DH>
>     Share this: Facebook<http://interspire.e-flux.com/link.php?M=3D287760=
&N=3D6959&L=3D21&F=3DH>|
> Twitter <http://interspire.e-flux.com/link.php?M=3D287760&N=3D6959&L=3D17=
9&F=3DH>
>
> *The MFA Computer Art Department at the School of Visual Arts* (SVA), in
> partnership with the New York Digital Salon (NYDS), presents *The
> American Algorists: Linear Sublime,* an exhibition exploring the elegance
> that can be achieved with a line through the use of programming a compute=
r
> and printing the work on paper with plotters, inkjet printers or other
> media. Curated by Grant D. Taylor, associate professor of art history at
> Lebanon Valley College, the exhibition will be on view October 26 through
> November 27 at the SVA Flatiron Gallery, 133/141 West 21st Street, New Yo=
rk
> City.
>
> *The American Algorists: Linear Sublime* features the work of digital art
> pioneers *Jean-Pierre ert*, *Manfred Mohr*, *Roman Verostko* and =
*Mark
> Wilson*. Their creative histories go back decades; Verostko and Wilson
> exhibited their work in the First New York Digital Salon, and Mohr has
> appeared in several NYDS shows. Mohr received the SIGGRAPH Distinguished
> Artist Award in 2013; ert received the award in 2012 and Verostko=
 in
> 2009.
>
> The New York presentation of the exhibition marks the 20th anniversary of
> the New York Digital Salon. According to Bruce Wands, chair of the MFA
> Computer Art Department and director of NYDS, "Computer art was initially
> seen as a trend. But today, art made with new technologies is viewed simp=
ly
> as contemporary art."
>
> In conjunction with the show, a panel discussion co-moderated by curator
> Grant Taylor and NYDS director Bruce Wands will take place on Saturday,
> November 9 at 2pm. Panelists include the artists Jean-Pierre ert,
> Manfred Mohr, Roman Verostko, Mark Wilson and A. Michael Noll, a scientis=
t
> and engineer from Bell Telephone Laboratories who, in 1962, created one o=
f
> the first digital artworks evelso on view in *The American Alg=
orists*.
> A reception will follow the panel discussion at 6pm. All events, free and
> open to the public, will take place at the SVA Flatiron Gallery.
>
> *The* *SVA Flatiron Gallery* (formerly the Westside Gallery), located at
> 133/141 West 21st Street, between Sixth and Seventh avenues, is open Mond=
ay
> through Friday, 9am to 7pm, and Saturday,10am to 6pm; closed on Sundays a=
nd
> public holidays. The gallery is accessible by wheelchair. For more
> information, call +1 212 592 2145.
>
> For the past 20 years, the *New York Digital Salon* has served as a
> catalyst for greater public awareness of digital art and helped fill in t=
he
> gaps in contemporary art history. It promotes the creative use of
> technology and innovation in contemporary art and contributes to cultural
> growth through educational and public programs, exhibitions and screening=
s,
> both nationally and internationally. The NYDS maintains an extensive onli=
ne
> archive and resource of digital art, artists and essays. A project of the
> SVA MFA Computer Art Department, the NYDS has received support from the
> NEA, Rockefeller Foundation, NYSCA, NESTA-UK and the School of Visual Art=
s.
> www.nydigitalsalon.org
>
> <http://interspire.e-flux.com/link.php?M=3D287760&N=3D6959&L=3D13411&F=3D=
H>The*MFA Computer Art Department at SVA
> * emphasizes creativity and a multidisciplinary approach to making art
> with computers and emerging technologies. Dedicated to producing digital
> artists of the highest caliber, the department has distinguished itself
> with seven Student Academy Awards. Graduate students' creative work has
> appeared in many international venues, including the Student Academy
> Awards, SIGGRAPH Electronic Theater, Art Gallery and Screening Room, Prix
> Ars Electronica, Whitney Biennial, Annecy, Ottawa and the New York
> Animation Festival. www.mfaca.sva.edu
>
> <http://interspire.e-flux.com/link.php?M=3D287760&N=3D6959&L=3D13412&F=3D=
H>*School
> of Visual Arts *has been a leader in the education of artists, designers,
> and creative professionals for more than six decades.  With a faculty of
> distinguished working professionals, dynamic curriculum, and an emphasis =
on
> critical thinking, SVA is a catalyst for innovation and social
> responsibility. Comprised of more than 6,000 students at its Manhattan
> campus and 35,000 alumni in 100 countries, SVA also represents one of the
> most influential artistic communities in the world. For information about
> the College's 32 undergraduate and graduate degree programs, visit sva.ed=
u<http://interspire.e-flux.com/link.php?M=3D287760&N=3D6959&L=3D2711&F=3DH>
> .
>

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>

Subject: Re: Need opinion on monitor
Wow, thanks for saving me money on crappy monitors~ So I guess I'll just
stick to my paradigm studio at the moment.

Not much going on recently. At first I was gonna partake in Guo Xi's May

published along with the exhibition. But then I dropped out and he finished
the project alone towards a different direction.

Now I'm thinking of getting back to working with audio, which is why I
(thought I) needed equipment. There's still gonna be app writing in between
me and GX, but that has to held up till he's done with his exhibition.

What are you up to? Had a wonderful trip I bet?


On Mon, Apr 21, 2014 at 3:42 AM, Dajuin Yao <dajuin@gmail.com> wrote:

> GY,
>
> In fact, your current audio setup, with Paradigm Studio would beat any
> pro studio monitor you can buy under $3000.
>
> But if you need to buy a separate pair, the ones you listed are no
> good enough. Yamahas are very soft and mild, we use some of them in
> school. They sound like plastic.  KRKs are to be avoided, as they are
> favored only by rap artists, since bass is very strong on them and
> highs very harsh.
>
> For real monitoring work, i would say, at least MACKIE MR8, better
> Mackie HR824, better, ADAM A7X. Best is Dynaudio BM6A (pro work).  I
> would go with Adam A7X if i were you, or if you don't want to spend
> too much on them, just Mackie MR8 MK3 is good enough.
>
> For audio interface, Focusrite Scarlett 6i6 is good enough.
>
> So, what are you up to ?
>
> DJ
>
>
>
>
>

> <http://aigany.us5.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e990059e83&id=cc189bc06f&e=e1528b21f5><http://aigany.us5.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e990059e83&id=6a30a326f6&e=e1528b21f5>

> *WEDNESDAY 19 MARCH 2014* | *6:30PM-8:00PM*
>
>
> *DUST & GROOVESADVENTURES IN RECORD COLLECTING*
> *PRESENTED BY EILON PAZ*
>
> Join us on Wednesday, March 19 for an impromptu event on the photographic
> journey into the rooms of the world's finest record collectors.
>
> Dust & Grooves: Adventures In Record Collecting began several years ago,
> as nothing more than a way for photographer Paz to engage in a personal
> project in his free time. Adrift in Brooklyn after emigrating from Israel,
> Paz -- a record collector himself -- thought it might be fun to start taking
> photos of people whose record collections were both larger and weirder than
> his own. These portraits turned into Dust & Grooves<http://aigany.us5.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e990059e83&id=ca272e12ff&e=e1528b21f5>,
> which quickly developed a global following, growing every time a new
> portrait was added. People all over the world enjoyed not only the beauty
> of Eilon's photos, but the interviews included with the collectors -- a
> motley, if generally charming, crew of obsessives who turned out to be at
> least as intriguing as the records they collected.
>
> Follow Dust & Grooves @<http://aigany.us5.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e990059e83&id=28c1129a16&e=e1528b21f5>
> dustandgrooves<http://aigany.us5.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e990059e83&id=43fe23a4b9&e=e1528b21f5>
>  #vinylbook

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: info@rainborecords.com
Subject: Ask about delivery time
Dear Sir/Madam,

I have 5 titles to press, 500 copies each. My time is tight. A small amount
of each title (~10=9620) needs to be sent to China by air to meet the
deadline of an exhibition by Oct 10. <x-apple-data-detectors://7> The
remaining copies will be sent to New York. Please let me know if it's
possible for you to meet the deadline, then I'll send you the specs and ask
for a quote (I provide CD-ready master files).

Best,

Yuan G.

I ordered one King Crimson - The Road to Red box set on Oct 6, specifically
for use in a project. But the project was subsequently cancelled, so the

regretfully return this box set to your company.

The transaction number for my order was 2807889959. I've received the box
set, but the T-shirt has never arrived, so I'd like to have the tracking
number first to find out the whereabouts of it.

Thank you, and sorry for any inconvenience caused.

Y. Gao

Hi Chris,

Sounds cool. Here's my specs for each title, and I want a quote for the
whole job (including mailing to China):

- 500 copies

- clear translucent vinyl, regular weight

- clear plastic (transparent) jackets, with stickers (text)

- white labels (with black text)

Thanks a lot.

Yuan G.

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Dajuin Yao <dajuin@gmail.com>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: *Chris Moss*
Date: Saturday, August 31, 2013
Subject: Re: Alpha Contact Form - Delivery Time
To: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>



OK here we go
Jump on www.zenithrecords.org
Look under specials, chose, than you may as well look up Preparing your
masters
Also check the templates for your labels
All our records are 180 G plus
All our labels are full colour so black on white is fine, your call if you
want full colour at no extra cost
There is no such thing as clear vinyl
Translucent or natural is what you are talking about
Now be aware that Natural PVC tends to be noisy much more than coloured or
black vinyl This due to the absence of fillers as well as plasticisers in
the material
Clear jackets not an issue included in the price shown, skip the foldover
jackets than
I am a little confused about the stickers! you want them attache to the
outside of the clear sleeve? you nee to verify or send me a photo of what
you want but there is time for that
Hard to get a cost of shipping to China, Man it is a very big place, so you
best send me an address or post code to where you want them to go and how
many
Is it for one title 20 copies? or for 5 titles 100 copies?
Clarify please
Cheers
C

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: "info@brooklynphono.com" <info@brooklynphono.com>, Fern Vernon Bernich <fern@brooklynphono.com>
Subject: Need to press five titles, with specs
Hello,

I have 5 titles to press, 500 copies each.

Specs:
- 12"
- Lacquer cutting (per side over 20 minutes)
- Plating per side (2 step)
- Labels printing: black and white (white labels w/ black text)
- No sleeves
- CLEAR plastic (transparent) jackets
- 140g CLEAR TRANSLUCENT vinyl
- Test pressing
- No shrink-wrap
- Stickers, text, on jacket

My time is pressing, has to be ready by mid Sep. Please give me the quotes,
including all setup charges (I provide CD-ready master files).

Thanks!

Juan


From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: John Also Bennett <john@brooklynphono.com>
Subject: Re: Need to press five titles, with specs
Hello John,

6-8 weeks should not be a problem. My greater concern would be, can you
provide clear transparent vinyl like the one in the attached pic, and a
transparent jacket to go with it? If so, what would their price be? Please
let me know.

Best,

Juan

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: John Also Bennett <john@brooklynphono.com>
Subject: Re: Need to press five titles, with specs
Hi John,

I understand that the turnaround time is usually 6-8 weeks, and I'm
absolutely fine with this window for the majority of the goods if they were
to be pressed.

However, my situation demands that at least 1 or 2 copies for each title (5
titles in total) be done by Oct 10 (4 weeks from now) so I can bring them
back to China for an exhibition.

Is that possible for you to just prepare this small amount of reocrds for
me before the Oct deadline? And I can patiently wait for the remaining
quantity, be it 8 weeks or longer. Please let me know.

Best,

Juan

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: <guoxi8839@gmail.com>
Subject: 
Chapter 1 ...

We live in a world consisting of the ubiquitous Other. In here, the Self's
existence is soly dependent on the Other, yet the former refuses to become
the latter. The Self is being formulated, yet incessantly negated by the
Other. What a perplexing but nonetheless enchanting mechanism! Experiencing
this world through the Other, the Self in turn becomes one of the Other to
refract what has been experienced...The so-called artist is an individual
who is constantly attempting to flee from the Other before his or her own
flesh vanishes, not, however, intending to embark on a search for the Self,
but, with a sense of justice, to shatter such a mechanism of the Other,
like a brilliant beam of light impaling through the heavy veil of mist,
revealing the truth in a flash...

In 2012, I fabricated a painter named Jia Siwen, then adopted his identity
to draw a few paintings. Later, I made a differnt group of works using my
own identity, including texts, posters, and mechanical installations,
serving as a counterpart to those paintings. Jia Siwen is a fictional
"avatar," very much like a newly created social media "account." Within
this framework, Jia Siwen is conceptually an independent subject, while
also being a form of existence of myself. If an individual identity can be
treated as a flat plane, then a fictitious identity is equivalent to
dragging up an "imaginary space" parallel to myself, within which all works
produced therefrom receive an interpretation.

Chapter 2 ...

The "body" here is a general construct, can be understood as a substance.
In a similar sense, the "faith" here does not lend itself to religion, but
to something metaphysical--ideology, concepts, and worldview, etc. Since
more appropriate terms are yet to be found as a replacement, "body" and
"faith" will be tentatively employed. Recently I begin to pay attention to
objects that carry special meanings. Those meanings are seemingly contained
within some invisible space inside the objects--like a flash drive wherein
some files of the .belief format are written. By similar construction, if
body is a vessel, then faith will be its filler. In this work I invented a
gesture. This gesture will allow people to turn their bodies into a medium
into which "faith" can be downloaded and subsequently infused into an
object.


Chapter 3 ...

This is the last work that takes fiction as its subject matter. During the
creation of Chapter 2, I developed a great interest in the concept of body.
This interest had driven me to draw a comparison between God, online
friends, and Jia Siwen, and discover their commonality of all being a form
of existence of "Logos," that is, they all existed prior to having a body.
Hence I tried to use the pair of "God" / "online friend" as material for my
work.

By having Mary conceive Jesus, God therefore possessed flesh. He is
"Logos." An online friend shares the same trait as God: Before an online
friend is met, he or she exists in a state of "Logos." It is not until such
a coming-together occasion that he or she acquires flesh. Such is the
sacred moment when Logos becomes Flesh. I sifted through the Internet to
find users with a God-related handle, then chatted with them to persuade
them to come to the exhibition, in order to complete an act of "Logos
becoms Flesh" in reality. I will prepare a banner printed with "Logos
becomes Flesh and dwell....)" (John 1:=
14), as well as a "Wel-become!"
met, to greet this online friend.

by:power2thepeople15<power2thepeople15@hotmail.com?subject=3DRe%3A%20Attitu=
de%20towards%20Audience>
Yeah the Osaka audience was brutal. Lots of really loud obnoxious coughing,
2 amateur photography incidents, which earlier on in the concert Keith
handled very respectfully, but what really made the experience bad is when
an audience member asked Keith how a genius could so easily be distracted
as he walked off the stage to (I believe) get the Japanese announcer to
remind the audience about noise levels. Keith then asked the general area
of the question who spoke, and when the man refused to identify himself,
Keith responded: "I'd like to meet the genius who wouldn't be distracted,
I'm just a human being," as he walked toward the piano. He then sat down,
contemplated, and was about to begin playing when the man found his courage
and loudly declared: "Mr. Jarrett, it was I who spoke." Keith had had
enough and said "that&#39;s it I'm done" and walked off. There was a 15
minute delay as someone came out to find the man who disrupted the concert,
but he had already left shortly after Keith. Keith then came back and
played for another half hour, but during the last piece another truly
exceptional cough ruined a beautiful quiet passage and Keith then decided
he was done and left the stage and did not play any encores.

He did play two full sets, so I'm not sure why the Japanese audience
demanded their money back. Encores are meant to be a gift, they are not an
obligation.

It's not pleasant being deprived of the encores because of the actions of a
few individuals, but at the same time, Keith as an artist did exercise
incredible patience, which was eroded thoroughly over the course of the
concert. An audience is only the sum of its parts, so if that audience
doesn't add up to the energy Keith needs, I guess its a shame. I also can't
really fault Keith because it really does affect his performance as I have
seen. A perfect example of this is the two Tokyo concerts before and after
Osaka, which were masterpieces. The only disturbance in either concert came
at the beginning of the second set of last nights show as someone's program
fell and made a loud noise 3 notes into a piece, which stopped Keith, who
said "at least it happened at the beginning," or something like that, then
took the idea back up and played an incredible piece.

If Keith were to merely pander to the audience, would we be treated to
concerts like these? I don't think so. But, at the same time, it does suck
to suffer because of the action of a few individuals. But, the clic=
rings
true in this case: the greater the risk, the greater the reward.

John A

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Yeniu Pan <yeniupan@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: about NN.
about NN

The owner of this Website is Ye-Niu Pan, presented in the online world by
the name of NN, her designer ego. NN originated from Niu-Niu, the pet name
of her childhood, an intimate way of saying "little girl" in Chinese.
Having practiced Chinese ink painting from the age of six, NN later decided
it was her calling to become a designer because, in her (little-girlish)
world-changing scheme, a designer signifies a charismatic figure, one that
possessed a higher transformative power than a painter. After gaining her
Master's degree in Academy of Art University in San Francisco, NN embarked
on a journey to the Big Apple (with her beloved dog Lucky), determined to
make her presence felt in the designers' world.

In 2011, NN began her career as graphic designer at a small (small-scaled?)
design agency in New York City. There she actively engaged in works of
branding, packaging, print and web design. The time spent in the agency saw
her mature as a multifaceted designer, who had made vital contributions to
the team in developing a number of diverse brands.

Two years into her work at the agency, NN deemed it was time for new
opportunities. Starting from 2013, she worked as an in-house graphic
designer for a global architecture firm. Since then she has perfected her
skills in environmental graphic design, producing results that exceeded
everyone's expectation. She also collaborated with the marketing team on
various successful marketing collaterals.

In the meantime, she was appointed as art director by a start-up team in
the fashion industry, helping to make crucial decisions on their overall
brand look and Web interface design.

NN firmly holds the belief that design innovation can greatly improve
people's life. Carrying such a faith, NN never stops learning new design
techniques, and is constantly seeking inspirations from the inner and the
outside world, where smart ideas blossom into life-changing designs.

For more on NN's background, please click here.


On Fri, Aug 1, 2014 at 1:43 AM, Yeniu Pan <yeniupan@gmail.com> wrote:

> Here it is honey, Thanks!
>
> NN

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>

Subject: Re: Reapplying to ITP, NYU?
Hello Midori,

It's been a year. How are you? I don't know if you still remember me, but
we had a discussion about (re)applying for ITP for the Fall 2014 semester
last year.

Last year I've had some changes in my job, which had affected my decision
to reapply for ITP, however this year I feel it's time for me to try again,
and I'm ready to become a full-time student once I'm admitted.

There's a problem I need to discuss with you. Last year I still have a
valid TOEFL score and I had sent a paper copy to ITP. This year the score
has expired, although I do have a digital photocopy of it. I have earned a
master's degree before from Columbia, and I've worked for two years in US.
Is it possible that I could only submit my TOEFL score from 2011 as a
digital file, instead of having to take the exam again?

Best,

GY

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: "Gabriele, Michael" <mgabriele@elliman.com>
Subject: Re: FW: Yuan Gao - Updates to Sale
Hello Michael,

There's bad news. About the deal. That's why I had to defer the talk with
attorney.

There's something I haven't been honest with you, about the occupation of
my father, who is actually a government official in China. That being said,
my decision of not disclosing this info was not because of the money is not
clean, but because I wanted to keep a restrained family profile whenever
possible.

I phoned my family this morning, asking money to be prepared and
transferred. However, I've learned that the money, currently in a third
country, in the hands of a third party, was not enough for purchasing the
property at hand. Worse, due to a recent constraint on banking policies in
China, which has created a huge problem and difficulty for esp. government
official to transfer money to anywhere outside of Mainland China, it's
almost impossible for my family to transfer more money to the
above-mentioned third party currently...

So without an escape plan, I find it inevitable to call the deal off. I'm
really really sorry, esp. for all your help and effort. I've tried
everything I can this morning, but there's really nothing I can do right
now...

Again, I apologize for all the trouble caused, and hope you'll understand
that I'm in really awkward position right now in the midst of all the
miscommunication and social turmoil in my country...

Yuan

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: patricia@psdnyc.com
Subject: This is Yuan (Niu-Niu's husband)
Hello Patricia,

Sorry for the confusion about Niu-Niu's medical plan. The medical plan, as
is offered by CHP along with NYU, works like this (in Niu-Niu's case, which
is identical to my case):

The whole plan costs around $2,100 per year, comprised of a fall/winter
period and a spring/summer period. The fall/winter period uses a one-time
payment of $840, which offers coverage from August of this year to January
of next year. The spring/summer period also uses a one-time payment of
around $1,300. Hence, although Niu-Niu's enrollment in my plan begins this
November, the price remains the same for her, had she enrolled in August.
In other words, although Niu-Niu has missed the first few months of the
fall/winter period, she still has to pay the full price in order to be
covered from November to the next January. That amounts to $840 / 3 months
(Nov, Dec, Jan) =3D $280 per month, for the remaining coverage of this peri=
od.

I hope this clarifies things a bit. Please let me know if there's any
questions.

Best regards.


*Gol Nng, 2015*


From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Yeniu Pan <yeniupan@gmail.com>
Subject: Fwd: This is Yuan (Niu-Niu's husband)
*Gol Nng, 2015*

Hello Patricia,

Sorry for the confusion about Niu-Niu's medical plan. The medical plan, as
is offered by CHP along with NYU, works like this (in Niu-Niu's case, which
is identical to my case):

The whole plan costs around $2,100 per year, comprised of a fall/winter
period and a spring/summer period. The fall/winter period uses a one-time
payment of $840, which offers coverage from August of this year to January
of next year. The spring/summer period also uses a one-time payment of
around $1,300. Hence, although Niu-Niu's enrollment in my plan begins this
November, the price remains the same for her, had she enrolled in August.
In other words, although Niu-Niu has missed the first few months of the
fall/winter period, she still has to pay the full price in order to be
covered from November to the next January. That amounts to $840 / 3 months
(Nov, Dec, Jan) =3D $280 per month, for the remaining coverage of this peri=
od.

I hope this clarifies things a bit. Please let me know if there's any
questions.

Best regards.


*Gol Nng, 2015*

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Yeniu Pan <yeniupan@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: NN website projects' content.
Shopisodes is an online platform providing curated, shoppable contents for
Asian females. Stories with relatable characters, a.k.apisodes, are
updated weekly as a display of styling solutions, allowing customers to
click through the scenes and shop for the best what online retailing has to
offer. The brand identity drew its inspiration from the lette, which
was then transformed into the shape of a swan as an embodiment of the
concept oransformed into a new loo.

The website is fully interactive, its interface designed to lead users
through the stories while offering a quick shopping access to the product
page. Shopisodes, currently under testing, is expected to launch on mid
August, 2014.



MIPIM is a powerpoint presentation for a conference pitching the idea of
"Influence of Millennials on Commerical Development" to real estate
investors. The presentation is itself a cornucopia of data and information.
In association with the concept oillennials," I converted perti=
nent
numbers into information graphics, creating so impressive a visual impact
that no showings of bare numbers can ever accomplish.

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Elizabeth <elizabethcaruso@nyc.rr.com>
Subject: Re:
Hi Elizabeth,

I just spoke to David. He's a very nice guy, I'm confident he's a good
attorney as well, so that should settle the thing.

However, there's something about the contingencies you asked me about
before that I wanna discuss with you (and the owner). As you know, I've
offered to buy the condo at its listed price without much bargain. However,
as I suddenly realized, I might have to put in an additional amount of
money for the renovation of the condo. I might very possibly need to change
the floor completely; the closets don't seem to be how and where I want
them to be I might have them redone. Plus the bathrooms and repaint etc.
All in all, it could add up to a considerable cost for me.

So, please be assured that I'm still willing to purchase the condo and make
a one-time payment, yet considering the future expense, I am really hoping
that the owner can give me a discount on the price. Sorry for not bringing
this up earlier, but things went a little fast for me that I couldn't raise
this topic until now.

So, please allow me to re-offer a purchasing price at 1.2 mil. It's about a
7% discount that I think will accommodate all the renovation expense for me.

Please convey my message to the owner, and again I apologize for any
trouble on your side.

Best,

Yuan

eb

a

> graphic design, collaborated with the marketing team on various successfu=
l
> marketing collaterals. In the meanwhile, I was art directing a start-up
> team in the fashion industry, helping to make crucial decisions on their
> overall brand look and user interface design.
>

> only reason I am willing to work for IDEO. I always firmly hold the belie=
f
> that design innovation can greatly improve people's life, which is one of
> the strongest reason making me choose to become a designer rather than an
> painting artist. I think IDEO is the place that takes a human-centered
> approach to helping organizations to build creative culture and sustainab=
le
> innovation design. I am very inspired by the concept oustain
> innovatio, I think IDEO has offered the best platform for any d=
esigners.

> position from IDEO.

> prints, web to environmental space design. I have a very organized design

Subject: Billing Issue
Hello,

I'm writing on behalf of my friend, Yeniu Pan, account number 954340, who
is currently not in the country.

My friend kept receiving billing statements from your billing office
showing that she had a pending balance of $40 due on Jul 8, which she had
definitely paid on Jun 5 with a transaction record on her bank account.
This repeating letter has been quite a nuisance to my friend, so please
inform your billing office of the payment, let them update the data more
frequently, and don't send any more letters to my friend.

Best,

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: newinternationalstudents@nyu.edu
Subject: Inquiry about application for I-20
Dear Sir/Madam,

I'm an international student who has just been accepted to NYU for the Fall
2015 semester. I'm currently working on H1B visa in the States, and my
department requires me to transfer to F1 visa to study as full-time student.

My questions are:
1, If I'm to stay within US till Fall, what is the approx. deadline for my
application for I-20?
2, Should the application for I-20, or any subsequent event like change of
status, happen after I quit my current job? If not, what's the relevant
condition that would require me to terminate my contract with my company?

I'm looking forward to your reply.

Best,

Yuan Gao

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: NYU Office of Global Services <NewInternationalStudents@nyu.edu>
Subject: Re: Inquiry about application for I-20
Dear Sir/Madam,

I am a new international student for the Fall semester in Tisch ITP. My id#
is N15764129. Here is my question:

I am currently working on H1B visa in the US, but am going to end my
contract with my company before the Fall semester begins. I have filed a
Form I-539 to USCIS for a Change of Status from H1B to F1 without leaving
the country, and they have received it on Apr. 28, 2015. However, after 3
months have passed I still haven't heard from USCIS. I'd want to know that,
in the worst-case scenario, is it possible for me to register as a
full-time student for the Fall semester, provided that my Change of Status
is still pending with USCIS by then? And also, what are the
implications/consequences if I were to terminate my H1B status with my
company before September, but hasn't received approval on Change of Status
by then?

Sincerely,

Yuan Gao

On Tue, Dec 30, 2014 at 2:46 AM, Dajuin Yao <dajuin@gmail.com> wrote:

> G>
> Just a word of advise regarding your statement. Of the three parts in
> the text, the first long section (regarding how you became interested,
> and descriptions of other's works in detail) really bears no relevance
> to your application.
>
> The essay is to tell ppl about you, and why they should take you in
> (from hundreds of applicants). So the key part is your last paragraph.
> What YOU want to accomplish in this program. So i suggest you cut out
> the first part (or condense drastically into a few sentences) and
> enlarge the last paragraph in to 2 or 3 paragraphs.
>
> Good luck,
>
> Dajuin
>
>

and if

ago, my focus was on automatic music tagging/retrieval. Lately e=

studying and working by myself on algorithmic composition mainly with tools
like SuperCollider and Max/MSP. Also starting to work on genera=
tive
visual and wish to do more in interactive/generative audiovisual art. I
know you have accomplished a lot in this field, and ibe great i=

Thanks for your time, and have a wonderful day!

Yuan Gao

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Peter Gerena <pg688@nyu.edu>
Subject: Re: NYU/TSOA - Status of Your Visa Processing
Hello Dan,

Thank you, I'm having a wonderful summer. I think it'll be easier to list
my answers to the questions accordingly:

(1) Yes, late March

(2) Yes

(3, 4 & 5) I have been living in New York and working on H1B visa. I filed
a Change of Status request to USCIS in late April to change my visa from
H1B to F1. The process takes 3 months on average according to USCIS, so I'm
expecting to recieve my F1 visa by the end of July.

Best,

Yuan Gao

       Room
Type:
 Room Type:
 One-Bedroom King Or Queen Suite With City View - Spacious Suite Features A
Kitchenette, Sofa Bed And City View. It Also Has A Mini Fridge And A Coffee
Maker. Wireless Internet Is Available, For A Fee.

Max 4 guests. Hotels may charge for additional guests.       Prepayment:
 Prepayment:
 No Deposit Will Be Charged.   Cancellation Policy:
 Cancellation Policy:
 Good news! This reservation qualifies for free cancellation up until 11:59
PM local hotel time on Monday, May 11, 2015. If cancelled or modified up to
3 days before date of arrival, no fee will be charged. If cancelled or
modified later or in case of no-show, 100 percent of the first night will
be charged.       Guest Parking:
 Guest Parking:
 Public parking is possible on site (reservation is not needed) and costs
USD 15 per day. Private parking is possible on site (reservation is not
needed) and costs USD 20 per day.   Internet:

            Prices are per day in USD           Important Information
      All
payments are to be made to the property during your stay, unless otherwise
stated in the hotel policies or in the room conditions.

All children are welcome. One child under 18 years stays free of charge
when using existing beds.One child under 3 years stays free of charge in a
child's cot/crib.All further older children or adults are charged USD 30
per person per night when using existing beds.Extra beds are not
available.The maximum number of children's cots/cribs in a room is 1.

The hotel reserves the right to pre-authorise credit cards prior to
arrival.

Pets are not allowed.

Upon check-in photo identification and credit card is required. All special
requests are subject to availability upon check-in. Special requests cannot
be guaranteed and may incur additional charges.

This Property accepts the following forms of payment:
American Express, Discover Card, Diners Club, Euro/Mastercard, Visa

This reservation is provided by our booking partner, Booking.com.

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: ym1356@nyu.edu
Subject: Fwd: CFP: Interactivos?'15: Material Cultures in the Digital Age
---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: *Midori L Yasuda* <midori.yasuda@nyu.edu>
Date: Tuesday, September 29, 2015
Subject: Fwd: CFP: Interactivos?'15: Material Cultures in the Digital Age
To: ITP Students <itp-students@lists.nyu.edu>



International Workshop Interactivos?'15: Material Cultures in the Digital
Age
Open Call for Projects


Open call for the selection of 8 projects that propose or reflect on the
role of daily objets in the digital era: digital and artisanal fabrication,
reuse, inventions, alternative uses and production, etc.

These proposals will be collaboratively developed during a prototyping
workshop from December 2 to 16, 2015.

Deadline: *October* *18, 2015 *(23:59 GMT+1)

Once selected, anyone can join the work groups by taking part in the *Call
for Collaborato**rs* that will be issued on *October 23*.


This workshop is part of the *Objects in Common
<http://medialab-prado.es/article/objetos-comunes> project in collaboration
with *Constant vzw (Brussels).

Workshop tutorsr: ar Gar, Josian Llorente and Wendy Van Wyn=
sberghe.


More information and submissions.

http://medialab-prado.es/article/interactivos15-culturas-materiales-en-la-e=
ra-digital

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Yeniu Pan <yeniupan@gmail.com>
Subject: Re:
The Cub Club was designed for MGchildreprogram that=
 tailors for
children from age 0+ (?). I had created 2 cub characters of different
genders, one for boys, the other for girls. Instead of using the common
colors of Light Blue and Pink for boys and girls respectively, I chose Teal
Blue and Orange Red as the two primary colors, because on the one hand,
they work more harmoniously with the new MGM brand colors, on the other
hand, they bring a brighter, more cheerful feeling to kids and their
families.


The Baby Lion characters were fully hand-drawn, and could be registered by
MGM as their own trademark. The secondary colors were created for making
patterns and other collaterals, such as kidclub cards, baby bibs=
, and
pouches.


We have provided some options for pouches, as you can see here (...)

We had also designed 2 alternatives for each pouch chosen from here. (See
lasers)


[Bathroom amenities]

The overall design look for babbathroom amenities is by using
typography only. They look big (voluminous?) and bold, but also clean
(crisp?) and modern. We didwant to reuse the Lion patterns too
profusely, which had already been applied on many other deliverables. As
you can see, the typographic bathroom amenity bottles sit nicely in the
overall design look, if not creating a greater harmony.

*Gol Nng, 2015*

On Sun, Aug 30, 2015 at 12:33 AM, Yeniu Pan <yeniupan@gmail.com> wrote:

s

> boys and girls, I use teal blue and orange red as two primary colors, whi=
ch
> works better with new MGM brand colors, which also brings morapp> feeling to kids and their families.
>
> The baby lion character is fully hand drew, MGM can own the lion characte=
r
> itself as trademark.

> We have given some selections for pouches, as you can see her> And we also designed two pouch options based one pouch we have selected
> here. (see lasers)

> bathroom amenities:
> The overall design look for baby bathroom amenities is using typography
> only. Big, bold but clean and modern. We dowant to repeat too=
 much of
> lion patterns, which has already applied on many other deliverables. As y=

From: None
To: None
Subject: None
Hi Anne,

Yes we went to see 365 Bridge yesterday. I liked the size of the apartment
very much, but also noticed that the rooms were a little gloomy due to lack
of sunlight/windows, esp. for the master bedroom. I know there must be a
tradeoff price-wise, but at this moment I think better
lighting/floor-to-ceiling/balcony etc. would be a huge plus for me.

Let me see if I can find some other listings online today, and maybe send
them to you so we can schedule a viewing?

Best,

Yuan

*Gol Nng, 2015*

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: ym1356@nyu.edu
Subject: Fwd: Open Call for Currents New Media Festival
---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: *Midori L Yasuda* <midori.yasuda@nyu.edu>
Date: Monday, October 5, 2015
Subject: Fwd: Open Call for Currents New Media Festival
To: ITP Students <itp-students@lists.nyu.edu>




*Title*: CURRENTS 2016: 7TH SANTA FE INTERNATIONAL NEW MEDIA FESTIVAL
*Deadline*: November 15, 2015

*Call*:

CURRENTcurators look for the unique ways artists use technology =
as a
tool for expression and communication, and ways that scientists,
programmers and developers are integrating the arts and aesthetics into
their explorations and projects.

The citywide Festival will be held in venues throughout Santa Fe: El Museo
Cultural de Santa Fe, the Center for Contemporary Arts, the digital dome
facility at the Institute for American Indian Arts, Santa Fe Art Institute,
Peters Projects, Axle Contemporary, Warehouse 21 and the Santa Fe Railyard
Plaza.

In addition to exhibitions CURRENTS 2016 offers panel discussions,
workshops and multimedia performances. All exhibitions and most events are
free to the public.

This YeaCategories include:
New Media Installations, Outdoor New Media Installations and Architectural
Mapping, Single Channel Video and Animation, Multimedia Performance,
Fulldome, Experimental or Interactive Documentary,
Web-Art/Art-Gaming/Mobile Device Apps, Oculus Rift, Robotics, 3D Printing
and Interactive Installations for Children.

Two Special Categories:
*Axle Contemporary Mobile Gallersee bottom of linked submission
guidelines page for info
*New Media New Mexico 201applications will open September 15 see
bottom of linked submission guidelines page for info

*URL*: http://currentsnewmedia.org/submission-guidelines-2016/

--=20
Frank Rose
Assistant to the Directors
Currents: The Santa Fe International New Media Festival
<http://currentsnewmedia.org>
713.885.3421
Facebook <https://www.facebook.com/currentsnewmedia> | Twitter
<https://twitter.com/currents_nm> | Instagram
<https://instagram.com/currentsnewmedia/> | Tumblr
<http://currentsnewmedia.tumblr.com/>

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Colin Geoffroy <colin.geoffroy@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: [Job] Design/build 4-5 simple sites (Sq. Space works)
Colin,

Thanks for sending me the sites that inspired you ! They are really good
indicators of what's desirable for your sites.

After reviewing it with my wife, we decided on a price of $20,000 USD for
the design and coding of 5 websites, with 5 revisions for each website.
This is calculated based on our freelancing rate, the estimated hours per
week, and the estimated total weeks we'd need to work on them.

I understand that this number exceeds what you expected, plus there's lower
offers out there. But please understand that lower cost leads to lower
quality design. My wife is a senior graphic designer and we live in New
York City, and this is actually a fair price for such jobs in New York
City, especially if you are familiar with what agencies like QNY Creative
charges...

Please let me know if you're still interested in hiring us for the task.

Best,

*Gol Nng, 2015*

From: Yuan Gao <quietboy.yuan@gmail.com>
To: Yuen Ko <821760408.sp@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: Metamkine_21012017_Clients_Exp_New Arrivals
*Gol Nng, 2015*

On Sat, Jan 21, 2017 at 4:57 PM, Metamkine <info@metamkine.com> wrote:

> And until February 21th, winter sales at Metamkine.
> http://www.metamkine.com/newsletters/SOLDES_2017_maj1.ods
> http://www.metamkine.com/newsletters/SOLDES_2017_maj1.xls
> http://www.metamkine.com/newsletters/SOLDES_2017_maj1.pdf
>
>
> New arrivals of this weekl
>
> http://www.metamkine.com/newsletters/21.01.2017_
> Clients_Exp_New_Arrivals.pdf
>
>
> Eryck ABECASSIS & Francisco MEIRINO, "La Gueule du Loup"
> FRAGMENT FACTORY
> Recorded at GRM Studios, Paris, 2015.
> Edition of 300 copies.
> "La Gueule Du Loup" explores raw improvisation in a crude, almost cruel
> manner. On stage the two musicians build musical sets free of pre-existin=
g
> structures or recorded sounds. The electronic matrix arises from the
> modules and is immediately propelled into the atmosphere.
> The two unpatched modular sythesizers first suggest a virgin circuit.
> Patches are built during the performance.
> Cosmetic memory plays a secondary role here, catapulted styles shoving th=
e
> idea of an unified single-style. This is another memory, where the patch =
is
> a substitution to ensure a sound coherence of elements, tones, micro-tone=
s,
> rhythms, order and chaos.
> frag 41
> CD
> 12,00
> https://soundcloud.com/franciscomeirino/francisco-
> meirino-eryck-abecassis-la-gueule-du-loup-extract
>
> Kuniharu AKIYAMA, "Environmental Music for Dining Room of Athletes'
> Village in Tokyo Olympics 1964"
> OMEGA POINT
> From participation in the early Fluxus to giving an introduction of
> Futurism, Kuniharu Akiyama (1929-1996), a renowned music critic, was
> involved in a vast range of activities. Particularly in the 1960s, he
> recorded a lot of music on tape for himself. To our surprise, the music
> compiled on this CD was actually discovered from a series of ambient musi=
c
> pieces played in the Athletes' Village at the Tokyo Olympics! During this
> period, Akiyama was fascinated by the sound of Sanukite stone from Sanuki=
,
> Shikoku island and he composed several ambient music pieces including thi=
s
> one. Despite the detail of the work have been unknown as the composer was
> already passed away, a guru of electronic musicologist, Koji Kawasaki,
> managed to reveal everything behind the piece.
> About the Works
> On this CD, there are two pieces of ambient music, which were composed by
> Kuniharu Akiyama for the Tokyo Olympics in October 1964. This music was
> composed with the sound of stones for a pair of stone speakers. To
> understand how it was developed, we have to go back almost two years from
> then. Around mid January in 1963, Kuniharu Akiyama was asked to compose
> Ishi no Uta (Song of Stone) for a TBS's TV program. It is said that Akiya=
ma
> was interested in Aji Village, Takamatsu city through a relationship with
> the sculptor Masayuki Nagare. This village is known for its over
> hundred-year tradition of granite quarrying. Akiyama planned to compose t=
he
> piece only by using stones and to do so he decided to visit Aji Village i=
n
> late January.
> At a dinner organized by Masanori Kaneko, the Kagawa Prefecture Governor,
> Akiyama found out that a beautiful "tone-stone" could be mined at
> Takamatsu. Akiyama then went to Takamatsu with Mitsuaki Sora, Nagare's
> assistant and CEO of the Okada Stone Industry. Akiyama later recalled the
> moment when he encountered the Sanukite stone, "I was deeply moved when I
> hit the natural stones of various sizes that had not been modified by
> artificial elements. Clear beautiful sounds with amazingly long sustain.
> Each stone had a different tone. Sharp and very powerful. To be honest, I
> never had thought that stones could have such a beautiful, strong and sha=
rp
> tone."
> From 1961, under the direction of the architect, Kunio Maekawa, Okada
> Stone had worked on a project to produce an exterior wall in stonemasonry
> style for the Japan Pavilion at the New York World Expo held in April 196=
4.
> To check its quality, a prototype was supposed to be displayed at a certa=
in
> space in Takamatsu city. This location became a project of collaborative
> work and was finally used as a ca. A collective formed by an archi=
tect
> Tadashi Yamamoto for construction design, Sora for facade and interior
> design, Akiyama for music and Junosuke Okuyama, an engineer of Sogetsu Ar=
t
> Center, for in-store sound design, worked on each assignment and the caf> "Shiro no Me (Eye of the castle)" was opened.
> Two huge stone speakers were installed on the left and right side of the
> entrance to the ca. These speakers were invented by Okuyama and pr=
oduced
> by Okada Stone. "Enjoy our speaker system that makes it possible to play
> music in the most musical quality. As only 'pure sound' will be projected=
,
> the sound is superb" was written on a flyer at the opening of the caf=C3=
=A9.
> This became possible because all vibration except for the paper speaker
> cone can be suppressed to the utmost limit by the weight of the stone.
> In Sogetsu Studio, Akiyama used the sound of stones as material and
> composed an ambient music piece called Shiro no Me; Music for Coffee Hous=
e
> No.1 for these speakers. This piece was assumed to be created by adding
> reverberation components to an improvisational performance with Sanukite
> and slowing down the playback to approximately one-half speed. This very
> primitive technique was chosen to take a full advantage of the beauty of
> Sanukite sound.
> About one year and a half later, for the Tokyo Olympics held in October
> 1964, two large dining halls called "Sakura" and "Fuji" were built in the
> male section of the Yoyogi Athletes' Village by architect Kiyonori
> Kikutake. It is said that while Akiyama composed an ambient music piece
> called "Music for eating" they decided to transport the stone speakers fr=
om
> the caShiro no Me" to the Fuji hall. Also in the front garden of=
 the
> Fuji hall, an ambient piece called Music for resting was played. Both
> pieces, which were in the similar composition style of Music for Coffee
> House, were recorded at Sogetsu Studio.
> In 1965, Akiyama argued, "the purpose of designed music is non other than
> promoting the composer's work, who designs music creatively, in a living
> environment. (omission) The composer would also have to participate in
> urban planning along with the architects and the artists. As we all know,
> it is because the composer himself/herself has also a role to dramaticall=
y
> shape a living space for today and tomorrow". The compositions compiled o=
n
> this CD can be considered as a practice of Akiyama's assertion as well as=
 a
> valuable innovation to the Japanese ambient music scene." Koji Kawasaki
> (electronic musicologist)
> [English translation by Toshiyuki Kawata]
> opa 021
> CD
> 17,50
> www.geocities.jp/paganrail/omegapoint/omega-sound/OPA021-1.mp3
>
> COMPILATION, DRONE-MIND / MIND-DRONE VOL.5
> DRONE RECORDS
> The series shows the various sides of todays experimental drone-music,
> especially focusing on newcomers and less well known acts from the world
> wide scene.
> "In an era when so much content is driven by personality, we offer instea=
d
> the challenge, or the respite, of interacting with sound on its own terms=
."
> [CLADE,]
> This LP-series from Drone Records is dedicated to the Drones of the World=
,
> and the Drones of our Minds. A kind of continuation of the Drone 7"-serie=
s,
> with artwork based on huge paintings by British artist Pete Greening. Dro=
ne
> Music is seen as more than a mere 'music style', it expresses an approach
> to perceive and understand the world. Drone-Mind and Mind-Drone build a
> circle of diverse inter-relations. The Drone as a metaphor for everything
> that vibrates, that releases energy - from atoms and elementary particles
> to the hum of the earth and the universe. The Drone as an entity that
> connects everthing that exists within our own "mind-space", perception an=
d
> self.
> Gydja (New Zealand). Enchanting female drone esoterica by an artist who i=
s
> also known through her stunning artworks for Cold Spring and other labels=
.
> Through magnetic winds and metallic clouds the long track "Gjallarbru"
> creates a wonderful secretful and sensitive atmosphere; very lonely and
> frosty, like a cold and clear consciousness released on a high mountain, =
on
> top of the world...
> Clade (Scotland / USA). Named after a notion taken from biology science
> (=3DMonophylum), this duo is based in Scotland and USA, alluring with ver=
y
> focused minimal drones on so far four releases. The two tracks presented
> here stand out with their use of somehow refractional, fibrous sounds,
> placed on monotonus drones with a very sedative and insistent effect...
> Monocube (Ukraine). This "ethereal drone" discovery from Ukraine moves
> musically through endless spaces, creating choral-like aural clouds and
> strange melodies =3D> self-supporting drones with an incredible width, wh=
en
> even the smallest particles of concrete microsound encountering are
> exciting, entering into a heavenly "song of the sirens" choir..
> Yrsel (France). Another bi-national project is this French-Swedish
> collaboration of Julien Louvet (2:13 PM, etc.) and C-J Larsgarden
> (Ondo),who released three albums so far. Their track "Krstnhmnbrtncrt"
> consists of very heavy, swallowing drones with atonal elements coming to
> the surface, diffus and poisonous but also lulling you into a deep (dead)
> sleep., slowly drowning in dense humming waves of cryptic drones...
> Solid silver coloured vinyl, graphic design by Abby Helasdottir, using tw=
o
> paintings by British painter Pete Greening; limited ed. of 400 copies.
> mind 05
> LP
> 17,00
> https://soundcloud.com/drone-records/
>
> Rev. Dwight FRIZZELL & ANAL MAGIC, "Beyond the black crack"
> PARADIGM DISCS
> Beyond the Black Crack was the concept of Reverend Dwight Frizzell, a
> musician, film maker, Doctor of Metaphysics and minister in the Universal
> Church of Life. It remains a little known classic, and one of the most
> unique listening experiences in modern experimental music. Recorded betwe=
en
> 1974 and 1976 in locations as diverse as factories, the pyramid opposite
> Harry Truman's grave site as well as more 'conventional' concert settings=
.
> Beyond the Black Crack is a dark, dizzying and exhilarating journey throu=
gh
> free jazz, electronics and environmental sound, all shattered by Frizzell=
's
> radical tape editing. This 40th anniversary LP re-release has been
> remastered from the tapes and adds a 4 page booklet with photos from the
> time. Pressed at Optimal in a numbered edition of 500.
> Beyond the black crack was originally released in mono in an edition of
> 200 copies by Cavern Custom in 1976 (cat. no. 6104-12), to commemorate th=
e
> First Annual End of the World Celebration, November 18 1976.
> Rev. Dwight Frizzell (tenor saxophone, clarinet, oscillator, objects,
> percussive objects), Mike Roach (clarinet, vocals, tenor saxophone), Kurt
> Eckhardt (flute, percussion, percussive objects), Rev. Tommy Gomersall
> (percussive objects, piano, vocals), Rich (percussion), Rush Rankin
> (clarinet), Rev. Jim Rogers (kazoo), Gary Jeffers (sousaphone, percussion=
),
> Bill Jones (sousaphone), Sylvia Thomas (harmonica), Radio Rich Dalton
> (guitar), Bill Scanlan (percussion, tapes)
> PD 06LP

> GR, "Propel tension on polyester base"
> OPAQUE DYNAMO
> GR's Propel Tension On Polyester Base is a decisive effort in tape
> recording, 13 private tracks taken from the archives of an adventurous mi=
nd
> and forming a mysterious sound diary, a core part in the evolution of GR'=
s
> style and a secretive work in progress highlighting an incessant appetite
> for putting a tentacular vision onto the recordable surface at hand.
> Among the tracks presented here - which were taped between 2008/2016 -som=
e
> are achieved in one blow with evident fulgurance, while some others are
> initiated early and completed years later in different spaces, non-simila=
r
> phases, bringing to the sound textures some unfathomable provenance ; the
> material is relentlessly tracked down by following the natural path of
> self-autonomy over space & time.
> The spectrum of styles & processes approached and developed by GR on thos=
e
> recordings is ultimately wide.
> Free construct open rhythm, hear the dead snare at your heels, freer rock=
,
> hard kicking grooves & serpentine pulse shall scare the hell out of ultra
> moving asses in the rush, saturation, dangerous proto-punk, the most
> menacing monster-fuzz downtown, cosmic elektronische & psycho tape loopin=
g,

> wicked street-punk delivery, non-chordal guitar excess, reel to reel

> Jim HAYNES, "Flammable Materials from Foreign Lands"
> ELEVATOR BATH
> "Flammable Materials from Foreign Lands" has been issued as a clear vinyl
> LP with gorgeous matte-finish jackets featuring artwork by Jim Haynes.
> Mastered by James Plotkin, it has been released in a limited edition of 3=
00
> copies.
> The new LP from Jim Haynes is a haunted and provocative endeavor,
> rust-covered and mysterious. It is the result of an immersive
> listening/recording process through which Haynes' singular techniques
> intersected with an unfamiliar, disquieting landscape...
> "The album was mostly composed, recorded, and sketched during an Estonian
> residency at MoKS for a program that was hosted by Simon Whetham and John
> Grzinich called Active Crossover. The goal of that program was to bring
> together various artists whose work pertained directly or indirectly to
> environmental recordings. When John asked me about what kinds of spaces I
> was interested in seeking out before I arrived, I mentioned that I would
> like to investigate sites that had a considerable amount of
> electro-magnetic disruption which I could capture on radio along with sit=
es
> of psychic distress.
> The Estonian landscape is pocked with abandoned buildings of considerable
> size and decay. Many of the excursions for Active Crossover engaged the
> large crumbling Soviet-era structures. Given that the electricity was off
> in many of these sites, I had to rely on shortwave to capture any
> electro-magnetic disruptions instead of any fluctuations from shitty wiri=
ng
> or weird Soviet power transformers... and the radio reception from that
> particular time and that particular place (i.e. southeastern Estonia) was
> eerie and unsettled. The crackle, drone, and noise is unlike that which i=
s
> heard in the United States, looming with a (possibly perceived) paranoia =
of
> the Russian state just a few kilometers away. That said, Estonia had
> experienced an encroachment from Russia as the Russian military
> kidnapped/extradited an Estonian intelligence officer who was on Estonian
> soil at the time not too far from where I was staying. Given the
> contemporary military actions of Russia reclaiming Crimea from Ukraine,
> this incident put many an Estonian on edge.
> The A-side to 'Flammable Materials' reflects this aestheticized paranoia
> through bursts of static, pulsed noise, and atonal sinews of sustained
> frequency. The B-side is wholly more introspective, cutting up an Estonia=
n
> radio broadcast into phonemes, disjointed phrases, and cryptic speech. Wh=
at
> few words that can be recognized from the Estonian pertain to the forces =
of
> globalization. From the context of someone who understands very little of
> the language, these snippets of a female voice clip like a surrealist
> collage or a Dada poem. Compositionally, I was thinking very much of Robe=
rt
> Ashley's "Purposeful Lady Slow Afternoon" and the Nurse With Wound
> recontextualization of such sounds." - Jim Haynes
> Based in California, Jim Haynes has exhibited internationally at the San
> Francisco Museum Of Modern Art, the Lausanne Underground Film Festival, t=
he
> Berkeley Art Museum, WestSpace (Melbourne, Australia), and Diapason (New
> York). Recorded media has been published through Editions Mego, Ghostly
> International, Drone Records, Hooker Vision, Intransitive, Semperflorens,
> Elevator Bath, and The Helen Scarsdale Agency. He has also been awarded
> residencies at the Djerassi Resident Artists Program (California),
> Recombinant Media Labs (California), Jack Straw Productions (Seattle), an=
d
> MoKS (Estonia). He has participated in a number of fruitful collaboration=
s
> with Loren Chasse, Keith Evans, Steven Stapleton, and M.S. Waldron. Until
> 2015, Haynes was the Vice President and Curatorial Director for 23five
> Incorporated, a nonprofit organization dedicated to the development and
> increased awareness of sound arts within the public arena. He is also the
> lone occupant at The Helen Scarsdale Agency.
> eeaoa 045
> LP
> 22,00
> https://elevatorbath.bandcamp.com/album/flammable-materials-
> from-foreign-lands
>
> Jim HAYNES, "Throttle & Calibration"
> HELEN SCARSDALE
> In 2015, Jim Haynes accepted a residency at MoKS in the village of Mooste=
,
> Estonia to collaborate and contribute to Simon Whetham's Active Crossover
> series. For this particular incarnation of Active Crossover, well over a
> dozen international artists were invited to this region of Estonia to
> collect field recordings and engage in a cross-pollination of ideas,
> strategies, and concepts that spawned from those recordings. The refuse
> from Soviet-era industrial farming complexes, the droned blur of aeolian
> harps, massive oil tanks,
> and the torrent of noise from the Arctic wind ripping through an empty
> water tower -- these were some of the sites that this chapter of Active
> Crossover archived, with each participant encouraged to trawl through the
> archives in use of composition, performance, installation, etc.
> Throttle & Calibration is the first in a series of albums that find Hayne=
s
> digging through the Active Crossover archive and grotesquely exaggerating
> the details into exploded compositions of volatile dynamics, nerve-expose=
d
> dissonance, caustic shortwave signal abuse, and a considerable amount of
> scarred metal. Marked as one of the more discordant works to date in
> Haynes' career, Throttle
> & Calibration finds company near the atonal, muscular compositions from
> Hermann Nitsch and the sour, industrial collages that pock the Nurse With
> Wound catalogue.
> Previously released digitally on Cica, Throttle & Calibration is
> fleshed out with an additional 20 minutes of material. Haynes is a Bay Ar=
ea
> artist, conducting research into the corrosion of sound, photography, and
> video. Previous recordings have been published by Editions Mego, Ghostly
> International, Intransitive, Hooker Vision, Elevator Bath, and the Helen
> Scarsdale Agency amongst others.
> hms 040
> cassette
> 9,00
> https://soundcloud.com/helen-scarsdale/jim-haynes-with-lead
>

> Alice KEMP, "Fill My Body With Flowers And Rice"
> ERRATUM MUSICAL
> Alice Kemp creates a cryptic yet coherent body of work through drawing,
> painting, objects, sound, audio composition, performance, and beyond. She
> has performed in Japan, USA, UK & Europe, and her more recent musical out=
put
> has been released by labels such as Fragment Factory and Harbinger Sound.
ill My Body With Flowers And Ricis Kemp's first full-lengt=
h release
> to vinyl - a compelling work of more than 40 minutes, including two
> collaborations with Rudolf Eb.er (Schimpfluch, Runzelstirn & Gurgelstock)=
.
> The album provides a stirring and intimate insight not only into AK's
> unique world of obscure,
> tense and delicate sounds, but also into one of the UK's most exceptional
> artists of today.
> This LP is a joint release by Fragment Factory (Hamburg) and Erratum
> Musical (Paris), released on the winter solstice 2016 in an edition of 30=
0
> copies on white vinyl.
> Recorded by AK, 2012-2015. Mastered by Giuseppe Ielasi, 2016.
>
> Alice Kemp (b.1972) works with dream-image-language and subtle trance
> states to create live-art performances and audio compositions. She lives =
in
> the South West of England, continually developing a practice of
> experimental music and audio composition, public and private ritual and
> performance, crude doll-making, drawing and painting.
> Her performances have been described as hypnotic, intense, unnerving,
> beautiful, dark and reflective, aggressive, confusing, meditative,
> pointless, brave, sensual, baffling, delicate, and absurd.
> EM 018

> 17,00

> KRENG, "Selfed"
> DRONE RECORDS
> Starting with soundtracks for the Belgian theatre-company 'Abbatoir Ferm'
> in 2007, Pepijn Caudron aka Kreng has since then created an impressive
> catalogue of work, submerging deeply into a cinematic musical world, ofte=
n
> built on 'classic' instrumental sounds, expressing a fascination for "the
> secrets of our culture, the roots of our collective fears and the hidden
> wounds, phantasies and rituals of our time" (as 'Abbatoir Fer' den=
otes
> their own programmation). Krengs compositions share a rare intensity and
> originality, immersing the listener into gloomy and surealistic
> atmospheres. "Selfed" is a work for a dance choreography by Kevin
> Trappeniers, a piece for a single dancer that relates to the phenomenon o=
f
> 'Self-Pollination' in Biology. "Selfed" is seen as a metaphor to overcome
> mental and physical barriers of the self and society, by "investigating t=
he
> notion of the energy of self and selfsacrifice". The three pieces suck yo=
u
> in with their spiraling sounds from the very first minute, ending in an
> early claustrophobic climax, from which structure and beauty is regained.=
..
> An interplay of circling dynamics.
> This 2 x10" vinyl (45 rpm) comes in a full colour double-gatefold cover,
> each record pressed in a different colour (blue-black / red-black), the
> fourth side contains an etching of all credit information. First ed. of 4=
98
> copies. Artwork design by Tilmann Benninghaus. Mastering: Peter Andersson=
.
> SUB-23
> double 25 cm
> 27,00
> https://soundcloud.com/drone-records/kreng-selfed-part-1

> RELAY FOR DEATH, "Natural Incapacity"
> HELEN SCARSDALE
> Relay For Death are the twin sisters Rachal and Roxann Spikula, whose
> noise mantras transcribe the harsh realities of urban blight that
> complicate and threaten their own survival. It was in the context of two
> month medical study that the Spikulas composed their debut album in 2009,
> amplifying the emptiness of hospital rooms into a ghostly pall worthy of
> the classic works by Maurizio Bianchi.
> Natural Incapacity sprouts from a similar research and development,
> manifesting from the sonic pollution that proliferates in their current
> residence of Richmond, California. Clocking in at well over two hours,
> Natural Incapacity was composed as a seamless, glacial accretion of
> locomotive grind, subharmonic environmental rumble, nocturnal street
> sweeping, and the quavering hum of toxic chemicals perpetually leached in=
to
> the water table. By design, Natural Incapacity's oil-stained drone is
> completely relentless, implying neither beginning nor end to this cycle o=
f
> contamination. Relay For Death's industrial meditation recognizes
> abjection, horror, and defeat as the prevalent conditions to existence.
> Even as a declared rejection to those conditions, Natural Incapacity is
> engulfed in a bleak nihilism constantly churning back upon itself. Grizzl=
ed
> antecedents can be found in the apocalyptic works of Maurizio Bianchi,
> Kevin Drumm's Imperial Distortion, and Organum's Vacant Lights.
> While intended to be a seamless document, Natural Incapacity is split ove=
r
> two CDs and does feature a download of the composition in unedited form.
> The physical edition features hand-rusted metal covers by the noted
> corrosion artist Jim Haynes and is strictly limited to 150 copies.
> hms 039
> double CD
> 20,00
> https://soundcloud.com/helen-scarsdale/relayfordeath-naturalincapacity
>

> SPLINTER ORCHESTRA, "Mungo"
> SPLIT RECORDS
> In March 2016 a 21-piece Splinter drove from their native Sydney to
> Adelaide, to perform as part of the Tectonics Festival. Midway they spent=
 3
> days recording in the vast desert recording studio that is Mungo National
> Park.
> Splinter has been developing alternative stratagems for making relevant
> large group improvised music since 2001. In recent years they've worked
> collectively - without individual authors and largely outside of the
> buildings usually associated with orchestras.
> mungo-coverThe new 3 CD set, 'MUNGO', their first release in 10 years,
> (since splitrec 17) presents an argument for a creative collective,
> sensitive to time/space - one that treats all the participants, be they
> performers, other species, or the wind, as equal players.
> Over the previous two years, they'd honed specific strategies involving
> motion that manifest differently wherever and whenever they are played ou=
t.
> These procedures were taken to the dry lakebed in far west NSW.
> There are 3 movements Sunrise, Sunset and Midnight on 3 CDs:
> 1. With birds and insects greeting the day amidst a ruined Zanci
> Homestead, they moved around two fixed stereo mics in specified modes Air
> Hockey and Wheel.
> 2. At dusk in the Woolshed (a massive wooden structure from 1869), they
> played Microphony: two microphonists, each with his/her own stereo mic
> weave through and around the space/band. At anytime they can handover to =
a
> fresh microphonist.
> 3. At midnight, after stargazing the desert sky, they recorded at the dir=
t
> Airstrip each relating to a pulsing bike light in the profound dark.
> At the heart of this project is an emphasis on context - Splinter takes
> it's creativity to one of the most powerfully resonant environmental,
> historical and cultural sites in Australia to ask the question, can we ma=
ke
> a new orchestral music for this land?
> split 27
> 3 CD
> 27,90
> https://www.subradar.no/album/splinter-orchestra/mungo
>
> Asmus TIETCHENS, "Soifantastique"
> AUF ABWEGEN
> 5" CD in full colour digipak carton sleeve and printed inner sleeve. CD i=
s
> off-set printed in half-metallized format, all designed by Asmus Tietchen=
s.
> Production: Okko Bekker. 500 copies.
> On "Soifantastique", two pieces unfocussed in every aspect featu=
ring
> blurring conmtours, spooled out harmonies and barely recognizable melodie=
s
> frame an extreme minimal, almost static piece in the centre. A piece of
> harsh, sharp-edges transparency. If this were not the music of a phantast=
ic
> nightlyx gathering, a soifantastque, one could liken these sound=
s to be
> signifiers of the setting we name the soft core inside a hard shell only =
in
> reverse. To know that this saying is as paradox as there cannot be a soft
> core might proof to be life-safing.
> Asmus Tietchens was born in Hamburg in 1947. Since 1975 he has been
> working as an independent musician; in 1980 he released his first solo
> record Nachtske. After producing a series of rhythmic and harmoni=
c
> albums for the Sky label in the early 1980s he released his first
> industrial record Formen letzter Hausmusik in 1984 on United Dairies. Her=
e
> Tietchens articulated his musical interests clearly: everyday noises were
> treated and at times deformed beyond recognition and placed into new
> contexts. Until now Asmus Tietchens has released more than 80 albums on
> international labels where he continues to explore the posibilities
> presented to him by specific sound sources (ranging from water sounds to
> pure sine wave tones). He has a more rhythm-oriented fake band project
> called Hematic Sunsets. Tietchens' work is rooted in a deeply sceptic
> gesture, marked by frequent quotes from the works of philosopher E.M.
> Cioran on his album covers. Asmus Tietchens is very outspoken about the
> state of affairs in noise music and contributes essays on the subject in
> various publications. Asmus Tietchens has been awarded with the prestigio=
us
> Karl Sczuka Prize of the westrundfunk (SWR) twice: in 2003 for hi=
s work
> Heidelberger Studien 1-6 and in 2006 for Trois Dryades. He lives and work=
s
> in Hamburg'
> aatp 57
> maxi-CD
> 10,00
> https://aufabwegen.bandcamp.com/album/soir-e-fantastique
>
> Robert TURMAN, "Solo-Works 1976-79"
> VINYL ON DEMAND
> Last copies !
> Robert Turman is an experimental musician and composer originally from Sa=
n
> Diego, now living in Ohio. Robert started recording music at an early age=
,
> using guitar, tape, vinyl records, and whatever instruments were availabl=
e.
> Some of these early experiments are to be found on the marvelous
> self-released 8-cassette box set "Chapter Eleven", which was re-issued on
> Hanson Records in 2010. Several more cassettes were released during the
> 80s, and have received great attention in recent years, due to vinyl
> re-issues by labels such as Spectrum Spools (Flux), Baba Tonnere (Spirals
> of Everlasting Change), and Dais Records (Way Down). Robert's increasing
> recognition and appreciation from the experimental scene have led to
> numerous releases on labels such as Hanson, Fabrica, and Cejero. Robert
> first rose to prominence as part of NON, collaborating with Boyd Rice on
> the classic 1979 single Mode of Infection, before leaving to pursue his o=
wn
> solo vision of music and noise. These are some of the earliest recordings
> that still remained unreleased until now.
> VOD 149.6
> LP
> 17,00

> Here's an important reminder about how to order correctly from Metamkine.
>
> We are not robots, we are humans ! When you send an order, someone is
> behind the computer and will check if the items are in stock, calculate t=
he
> postage costs and send you an answer.
> Some days it can take a bit longer.
> So if you don't have an immediate response, please be patient. But if you
> don't get an answer in the next 48 hours (business days), then please
> contact us as it may be possible that our message was lost in virtual spa=
ce.
>
> And if you want to cancel your order, don't forget to tell us.
>
> Thanks
